You could tell they were ready for us to leave, but because of the quiet neighborhood location, it's not an ideal spot to hail a cab, so we asked the host to call one for us. He does, and then proceeds to leave for the night. Tacky.

It is very cold outside, we we wait inside for the cab, as the busboys are mopping and blowing out the candles. We finally felt so awkward and almost intrusive, that we just waited outside for the cab that NEVER CAME.  We saw a cable car coming downhill, so we hopped on that and took it to California where we went and got martini's at The Big Four inside the Huntington.

The ambience (and company :) was so great that we chose to overlook some of the things that should have been handled better. This restaurant is not cheap, I'm sure the bill was over $200 for the 2 of us. The least they could have done was waited until we were in a cab to turn off the lights and lock the door.

I'll be back, but the service better be a little more accommodating.
author: Lauren G.

description: i had such a cozy dinner at venticello. i liked their interior, service, and foods. my boyfriend and I made a reservation for saturday night. we got there about 30 min early, but we could sit after waiting only for 5 min. The waiter was polite and nice. we had a light beer (i don't recall the name of it) and butter squash soup. both were very delicious, especially the soup. ps- boar pasta is so so.
author: Christy C.

description: first time visiting this restaurant that was suggested by the very friendly concierge at the hotel that i was staying at.  this place did not disappoint when it came to the quality of food and the awesome service provided by tim.   he made sure that i felt taken cared of and i appreciated his attentiveness especially because i was dining alone.  i felt a bit uncomfortable because most of the people dining we couples.  nevertheless, this is a good place to visit when ur around this neck of the woods.
author: Classy C.

description: This is one of my most recommended Italian places in city just for the Carbonara!!!  The house made pasta is heavenly soft!  I used to live a few blocks away and would post up at their Manhattan size bar(aka small, dark and cozy) talk to the bartenders and have the Carbonara.  For tourists it also is the most beautiful located restaurant in the city, on the hill overlooking the cable car line and bay bridge.
author: Cameron A.

description:
Great location, very warm interior design and atmosphere. 

I called around 830pm on a Sat. night to ask about their last seating and was told by a friendly gentleman that it would be good to arrive by 930 which we did. Upon arrival the man remembered me calling and was gracious in person too. He gave my girlfriend and I our choice of seating as the restaurant was only half full at that time. 

Our server was friendly and recommended some nice wines by the glass. I had the sauvignon blanc. It was delicious. (Wattle Creek, Mendocino, '08)

The Cesar salad with anchovies was fresh, crisp and tasty though not the best I've had. We split it by the way, and without us asking the server brought it to us in individual servings. A nice touch.

I had the pasta special of the evening (spacing on the name) which was pretty good, and my "date" had the fettuccine con salsiccia which we both liked quite a bit. 

We looked at the dessert menu but then realized we still had a few pies in the fridge left over from Thanksgiving. :-)  

In short, everything was yummy but nothing was blow-your-mind spectacular. The presentation was on par with other restaurants of the class, and the service was totally solid. It's a nice place to take a date or a few friends. I would definitely go back again.

The whole meal came to just over $85 incl. tip. Very reasonable.
author: Evan A.

description:
While looking for a cozy spot to take my BF for a long overdue date night, I decided on Venticello.  Neither of us had been, and we are fairly new to the area.  I made my reservation via OpenTable for 8:15 on a Sat night.  

Valet parking was easy, and only $10 (w/o tip).   The entrance is a little odd, without much room to stand, and the little waiting hallway is right by upstairs tables (luckily they were empty when we came in, or I would have felt kind of awkward being practically ON their table; LOL).  Interesting spaces are probably the norm for small buildings around here, though :)  The host was very friendly, but he did ask us our reservation name three separate times in the span of under 10 minutes, as well as the other party standing next to us.

But he had ever so nicely saved us just the type of table I requested, one off to the side of the other tables.  He thanked me by first name as he seated us, which was a nice touch.  

The atmosphere/ambience is really where it's at for this restaurant.  Mind you, we were sitting downstairs, and I don't think I would feel the same if we had been sitting upstairs right next to the door/galley...
The lighting is really cozy, and although we didn't have the best view out the front windows, we could still catch glimpses of the bridge/bay.  Very pretty at night.  

We started with wine and shared the heirloom tomato/buffalo mozz/arugula starter salad, which was amazing.  I don't remember what kind of balsamic dressing was on it, but it was delicious.  We had plenty of bread with garlic oil to eat while waiting for our meals, although the wait was quite short.  I had the herb & goat cheese ravioli with basil/garlic red sauce, and my bf had the filet mignon.  He actually let out a sigh with the first bite :)  The ravioli portion was a little small (and that's coming from a small person, lol) but still SO good.  Sauce was very yummy.

We finished the meal with the chocolate torte (almost truffle-like in texture, yum) and he had the vanilla ice cream with espresso.  
Our waitress was pretty to the point, not overly-friendly or attentive, but I am OK with that since we were trying to have a romantic date night :o)

4 stars for great experience, we will probably be back!
author: Anna S.

description: The pastas were excellent (I have better but mostly much worse).  The veal was meh.  The salad was fine but not inspired.  And the arancini balls were delicious.  4.5 stars if I could.  And the neighborhood is super residential, which I like.  This is a neighborhood place.
author: Gabriel B.

description: The space is romantic and very nicely decorated in a quiet Nob Hill neighborhood. We ate early on a Wednesday because we had tickets to Cirque du Soleil so it was nearly empty at 5:45 but quickly filled up around 6:30. Made reservation through 'Open Table' and it actually worked! Wait staff was attentive without being obtrusive. Menu was a tiny bit limited but I'm a picky eater. Pretty good wine list, albeit a bit pricey, but it is Nob Hill. Food was better than good but not quite amazing. I'd go back to try some other stuff if I was in the area.
author: Nick D.

description:
We tried our luck by going into the city for a performance at the Masonic Center on a Saturday night without reservations. That's either brave or stupid...I'll let you be the judge of that.

We walked down the street and found Venticello, which had been favorably rated on Yelp, so we ventured in. The restaurant was packed, but to our amazement were two vacant stools side-by-side at their cozy bar. We sat and were immediately greated by Daniel, who we first thought was the bartender and later realized was running the restaurant. 

I had a clean and generous Saphire martini to start with and my wife had what lived up its billing as a great Cosmopolitan. We started by splitting a half order of the mushroom and gorgonzola gnocci. It was out of this world. The flavor was intense and rich. There was cream in the sauce, but this sauce is much more about flavor than about the cream. 

We continued by splitting an excellent salad that came with what obviously was a housemade honey dijon dressing that wasn't your typical sweet TGI Friday's syruppy goop. This dressing was simply oil, honey, herbs, dijon and I'm guessing a little balsamic. 

We then wrapped up the evening by splitting seared Ahi with a lemon caper sauce on it served over polenta and fresh spinach. Everything was fresh and flavorful, especially the fish, which was served perfectly seared and rare inside.

This is a restaurant we will definitely return to so we can experience more of the great service we received there and sample more of the terrific food. Next time, we'll even book a reservation, though we'll miss hanging out at the bar with Daniel and the other friendly locals we met there.
author: Eric W.

description: I live within blocks of this cozy restaurant and have had some good meals in the past.  Monday night was a huge miss.  The only good dish our group of four had was the prawn appetizer.  The sole, pork chop, carbonara and veal were all ill-seasoned or cooked improperly.  Not sure if management has changed or the better chefs were off that night but I will think twice about coming back.
author: John N.

description:
Venticello offers a taste of Italy - both in its delicious food and in gracious service.  The warm, intimate atmosphere embues a rustic elegance, while the high ceilings open the space.

Italian wine selections are not too overwhelming in number, but quality definitely wins over quanity here.  The staff is always knowledgeable about what blends to pair perfectly with your meal, and very accomodating.  

The Veal Scallopine is divine - likely one of the best dishes in San Francisco.  Add to that, the trolleys rolling by in front of this quaint restaurant in Nob Hill, you get the sense of being on vacation in San Francisco - tucked away in this little gem of a restaurant that could easily be adjacent to Rome's Spanish Steps, without the crowds, of course.

A great place for a romantic night on the town or a small group of friends and family.
author: Lauren E.

description: What a wonderful place tucked in Nob Hill.  I thoroughly enjoyed the meal and the service was top notch.  I cannot wait to return!
author: Denise C.

description:
Meh... the food is okay but nothing extraordinary and even though everybody says this place is so romantic, I really did not get that feeling during our anniversary dinner this summer. 

I can see that the upstairs can be more cozy and romantic, but the downstairs has high ceilings, lots of noise, and nothing special in the decor. Maybe because it was summer and at 8:30pm it was still bright? Maybe you need to go when it's dark? I don't know, but overall I did not find this place special in any way: the service was good but not really elegant so just normal, the food was just okay (there are so many other better Italian restaurants in SF), the atmosphere was just okay... so what's the big deal? 

I gave it three stars because of its location. Yes, LOCATION is its best feature: right in the heart of Nob Hill, on the top of the hill, and along the cable car line. It was super romantic to walk around the area before and after dinner (of course we did not have the common wind and fog). 

I would recommend this place for someone that wanted to take time before and after dinner to take a romantic walk, even if short and enjoy looking at the pretty Nob Hill homes - just plan do do that on a day when the fog or the wind are not taking over. Or if you were staying in a hotel on Nob Hill, this could be a good option: you can walk over or take a short taxi ride. Just know this is not the best food you can get in SF, but it's okay, not bad.
author: OcchiDiGatto S.

description: Decided to try this place with my bf and his parents. We we're extremely impressed with the food. His parents split the gnocchi rack of lamb and Caesar salad..they were very very pleased. I had the filet mignon and my bf also had the lamb. It was such a nice vibe and great atmosphere..service was on point as well. Overall, this will be my go to Italian spot.
author: Jenny K.

description: Very Small and cramped.  Was reccommended by concierge at Fairmont.  The food was fine.  Service was OK.  Nothing Special.
author: Kathy G.

description:
JamesF
Expensive, but a truly enjoyable dinning experience.  Presentaion of the cuisine was enticingly impressive, the wine list, while not extensive, was moderately priced, the staff exemplary, the only downside......in this purported romantic atmosphere,......the music....it so didn't fit the ambiance that I believe they strive to create.....something classier and with a lower beat would have been, in our +50 experience, conducive to a feeling of romance!
author: Sue F.

description: We were disappointed...the food was not bad overall but it was pretty expensive for a rather small plate of food, and we thought the bread was pretty lame.  We had the ravioli and the gnocchi, both had great flavor but both were quite small.  Just down the street was the Nob Hill Cafe and their pastas looked much bigger and much more delicious!  We'll try them next time.
author: Vince P.

description:
This breaks my heart because Venticello has always been a special neighborhood spot, but on Saturday night, disaster befell us. 

I won't complain that our table wasn't ready when we arrived, causing us to wait 15 minutes in the cramped breezeway upstairs as passersby and disheveled busboys jostled us. 

And I won't even complain that our waiter was so disengaged that I suspect he's studying for the MCAT in between visiting tables.

But once a restaurant bombs on the food itself, it's time to complain. In short, our entrees were cold and overcooked. And amazingly, the diversity of our choices (heirloom tomatoes, lamb, pork, and beef) was counteracted by the chef's use of the SAME exact balsamic reduction sauce on all four. Had they run out of ingredients? 

My boyfriend, who's normally good-natured and forgiving, simply had to send back his dish when his mashed potatoes and pork medallions arrived cold. He mentioned, too, that he'd expected the pork medium rare (as was communicated), but instead, had well-done meat. Our waiter took this in stride, but the situation was remedied with a microwave. Mike's dish was returned to him five minutes later, warmed up, still overcooked, and grossly underhandled by management.

The meal for all four of us was lackluster and disappointing, and I felt personally let down by a restaurant I've always counted on. I'd like to chalk it up to an off night, but just the same, I don't think we'll ever go back to test that theory.
author: Vesper L.

description: We live in SF. There are dozens of great Italian restaurants I'd opt for before Venticello. The food was mediocre, cocktails O.K. and service less than wonderful. It's not terrible but in SF, especially for the price (it was $$$), you can do much better. Delfina, Allegro, Milano, Frescati, Ideale, and Seven Hills are all better.
author: Cheyenne C.

description:
I have mixed feelings about this place.  My hubby and I went there for my birthday.  Here's my list of pro's and con's:

Pros:
- GREAT food!  Homemade pasta, tender cuts of meat, etc...
- Beautiful atmosphere (warm & nicely lit)
- Super friendly host / bartender
- Easy location to find by taxi
- We were seated immediately (no waiting for table)

Cons:
- The food is on the expensive side and you don't get that much of it. 
 - Our waiter was REALLY rude.  He was definitely fresh off the boat from Italy and his attitude was horrible.  We could tell that he was pissed off because we didn't order any alcohol.  As soon as we turned down wine, he became short and showed little to no attention to our table.  As a result, we left him a very minimal tip because of his poor attitude.  Our waiter really ruined the meal for me.
author: Andrea K.

description:
This was quite possibly my worst New Year's Eve experience after joining 3 others for the NYE Price Fixe special menu.  This "special" ended up leaving me short of just over $100 but that's not what bothered me.  

1) Disorganized: we had a to wait about 20 minutes past our reservation but we also saw someone wait an hour past his reservation and end up leaving. 

2) It took forever: We were seated for roughly 2.5 hours which is fine for a Tarantino movie but not for dinner.  I think we were on the faster end as well because we were later in the evening.

3) The food wasn't that good in my opinion.  I had the Salad, Oysters, Cavatelli pasta, lobster and dessert.
-The salad could have been made quickly with a handful of baby lettuce.
-The oysters were what killed me.  The first was OK but the second was so BAD I couldn't look at the plate anymore.  I had a hard time getting that taste out of my mouth and the thought of it out of my head for the remainder of the meal.
-The pasta was very good and this was the long highlight.
-The Lobster was ok.  You didn't get much but I wasn't expecting a gigantic lobster tail.  Take it or leave it.
-I'm not a dessert person but those at the table who were seemed to enjoy.  However, at that point we just wanted to go!

  I will give them 2 stars instead of 1 because I think some people lagging at their tables earlier in the night messed everything up for them.  That's out of their control.  Still, they should have done something for those waiting (charging someone who waiting an hour past his reservation for wine?).  Also, it did not look good when friends of the owners would drop in and get treated like royalty.
author: Digger L.

description:
Tried this place - review about it here http://tummytravels.org/2010/06/17/a-fortnight-in-fog-city/ - and was not disappointed! I made sure to order the veal dish after all the yelp reccs (+ our waiter told us it was the most popular dish on the meny) and absolutely LOVED it.  For starters we tried the grilled prawns with pancetta - spicy and salty, but delicious.  The wine was fabulous, the mood very romantic and the feel of the place sooo Italian.  A lot of people around us were on first dates so you are not alone, in case that's what you're thinking :)

Definitely recommend!
author: Tash P.

description:
Atop Nob Hill and is tucked away and almost hidden among the residential apartment buildings. The décor is almost like a Tuscany feel, deep reds and light orange/browns. The restaurant itself has a 2 level dining room. Larger parties on the bottom first level for "family style" dining feel with round tables.  Dimly lit and romantic.

Mediocre bread served with a dish of olive oil mixed with chopped garlic. Pastas are great.  4.0 stars for fresh pasta but the one complaint I have are the sauces are loaded with butter and creams.  

 We called to make a reservation, none were really available till 8:30. 
 Once we were waited on we ordered.  I'm sorry but the food was only average in my book. I got the risotto with prawns and it greatly lacked flavor. I don't know if they forgot the seasoning or what was going on, but the entire meal I felt like something was missing. 

Antipasti and secondis were about 3 stars.  Nothing really special.  There are some affordable bottles of wine under $50.  This is a good date place, just order the pasta tho.  A bit on the spendy side for pasta tho around 17-20, but it's so filling and tasty. At best the service was robotic--like timely, with zero personal touch. It's not the greatest Italian I have ever tasted, but it is a very enjoyable Italian meal in comparison to its Italian competition in the area. Really, I would give the food a 3 1/2 average, with some individual dishes deserving a 4 1/2
author: Curry Man X.

description: This is a lovely and charming restaurant hidden on the romantic streets of Nob Hill. The food was delicious- the carbonara is not to be missed!
author: J M.

description:
Searching for a cozy little hole in the wall kinda place for dinner with friends?  Well, you might just want to try out Venticello.  I was staying over in San Francisco the night before a flight out and looking for some place in the Nob Hill area that I could walk to for good eats.  Who wants to eat hotel food in a foodie city like San Francisco, right?  My first choice was packed to the gills, so i strolled a bit further down the street to find Venticello on a quite street corner.

They have a nice, but not expansive selection of wines by the glass.  The chianti I had was delicious.  The food is not wowszers in terms of innovation or anything like that.  It's Italian classics done well.  I had the carpaccio and the pollo marsala.  The carpaccio was good, but I really enjoyed the the pollo marsala.  The chicken was perfectly cooked, the sauce was rich and flavorful, could have used a more generous scoop on the mashed potatoes, but other than that, a very enjoyable dish.

If you're in the neighborhood, I'd recommend giving them a try.
author: Mike B.

description:
LOVE.

Came here for my wedding anniversary with my darling hubs at the suggestion of Jeffrey, the bartender from the nearby Huntington Hotel who is apparently a regular (thanks, J!).  Atmosphere was fantastic (despite several man-cougars lurking at the table nearby who blatantly checked me and the girl at the table next to me out when we got up from our respective tables) and service was stellar.  Be sure to try the herb & goat cheese ravioli (I die!) and tiramisu.  WIne selection was fabulous and reasonably priced.  My hub and I split the pear & gorgonzola flatbread pizza as an app and adored it. The bread comes with a delicious roasted garlic sauce that I'm STILL salivating over.  

Our server was attentive without being annoying, which we appreciated, and brought out a dessert, gratis, complete with candle for us to blow out to celebrate year #1 of wedded bliss (adorable!).  We loved Venticello and will most definitely be back when we're next in the Bay Area.
author: Holly A.

description: This was a great restaurant to visit.  My parents had just flown in from Australia and this was their first SF meal.  I loved the trolley cars that rattle past and also that the restaurant is on a big hill so it is a few levels high but still very small.  Our waiter was great, he had visited Australia and NZ so knew all about our wines and was a genuinely nice guy.  I would really recommend this place.
author: Karen D.

description: Cold, impersonal, arrogant and agonizingly slow service.  They act like they're doing you a huge favor by waiting on you.  The tables are too close together and too close to the door...we froze every time the door opened, and had to pull the candle close to read the menu because it was too dark.  The one star is for the food, which was good, but it was definitely not worth the trouble.
author: Melissa S.

description:
Apparently the other reviewer/ dude here doesn't understand.  Good italian food is about loving life not just dinner. Italian dining is a total experience.  When someone finds a nice neighborhood restaurant like Venticello's they tell their close friends and bring them there as I have done.  But, you got to do it right.....  Doing Italian right is about optimizing the pleasure quotient.
  
Venticello's has its own flavor.  The main dining area is very cozy.  It has kind of a rustic wooden italian feel to it.  You can see a sliver of the view down to the bay bridge from the corner window.  This is all part of the atmosphere. The wine list at venticello is quite good. But I later found out that venticello's offers a corkage fee.  So, the last time we brought in two bottles of vino, which we happily consumed. I split their fresh romaine caesar salad with a friend and ordered the mushroom gnocchi.  It was very good. Also, the folks who work here are pretty cool and have a passion for the place. 

So in summary, the venue, plus great food, plus italian wine, (sangiovese), plus a little passion, plus good company, equals a beautifully satisfying dining experience.  To sum it up; this place is a slice of the good life.
author: Georgio N.

description: Stumbled upon this quaint restaurant while I was up in the Nob Hill neighborhood.  I've tried both the lamb tenderloin and fettuccine with fennel seed and sausage (substitute the cream sauce for marinara).  I like the food, the service, and the cozy atmosphere here.
author: Kent W.

description: Piss poor service and mediocre food from the start. Had to beg for someone to actually take a drink order and the maitre' de was a complete ass when we politely asked for s few cocktails for some parched friends. Gnocchi was good and every single other dish was barely above Denny's in quality and presentation. Had heard good things and this was th3 third strike on a Saturday night. Sadly I wasted 3 bills on a crap dinner and the only thing i left satisfied with was the 15 year port which was poured from a bottle... Just don't go.
author: Erik C.

description:
Wow 4 stars? Who are these people? If I could give less than 1, then I would. I actually was inspired to start yelping because of this crappy restaurant. 

First let me say, this was the 3rd strike for this restaurant... 

Experience 1 was a take away experience when we were dismissively blown off by the phone by an extremely rude and far-too-busy server for just desserts. This experience was lack-luster in terms of food quality, but not enough to write it off despite the poor experience and better production from people who specialize in desserts. 

Experience 2 was for my birthday. The same poor server greeted us (without reservations) for my birthday and told us they were not able to accommodate us without a res until 9:30. We told him to call us if something opened up and there was NO desire to - he was barely even willing to write the number down on a random piece of paper which I'm sure he threw away when we walked out. 

Experience 3 was today. Ordered the shrimp app and the bresola/mozzerella appetizer. The shrimp were overcooked, horribly dry and completely unappealing. Despite eating only 1, the server/host said nothing. Next the deliciously (sarcastic) feet-smelling bresola/mozzerella pizza was completely unappetizing and nothing like a supposed Italian pizza. Still nothing was said when I dropped $35 eating 1 shrimp and 1 slice of pizza.

This isn't really a surprise given that we had the EXACT same experience at Nob Hill Cafe (same owners/business) a few weeks ago. 

You could get better quality at the Olive Garden. (and in case you didn't know, Olive Garden is about as far from traditional Italian as you can get). 

Head to North Beach for something better. 

If you want arrogance, over-priced food, and lack-luster food, then please feel free to make a reservation or wait until 9:30 to dine.
author: Joe D.

description:
The best thing here is not on the menu, the bread. 

Plain and mediocre food. The famous view is more of a no-view. Service was fine. Decor is outdated, I can see how some might find it "romantic" though. But the romantic ambiance disappears quickly as it gets really crowded and noisy in there. There are plenty of great restaurants in the city, so there is really no reason to go to this one.
author: Maggie X.

description: Tucked away in the middle of Nob Hill, I had no idea this place existed.  Cozy, romantic atmosphere. Good food, but nothing to write home about. Worth checking out though!
author: Priya N.

description:
We went here after getting several enthusiastic reviews from friends, and unfortunately it was rather a disappointment. The food wasn't terrible, but it was certainly nothing special. If I could, I would probably give it 2.5 stars.

The ambiance and service (including the valet) were perfectly fine so the evening was still pleasant, but the food was really meh. We brought our own wine.

My fiance and I shared several dishes:

charcuterie appetizer
arugula mushroom pizza
carbonara
Then I had the lamb and he had the filet mignon.
All in all it was about $175

The charcuterie was okay, but for the price not very interesting (pretty much your basic spread, nothing special. The waiter didn't even bother to tell us what the different meats were).

The pizza was probably my favorite of the courses, but it was not off-the-charts spectacular. It did have a very nice crust, though.

The carbonara was decent but a little too creamy for my taste (not enough egg) and the pasta was slightly gummy.

The biggest disappointment were the entrees--flavorless and blah. My lamb didn't even taste like lamb and the vegetables it was served with were similarly tasteless. I think my fiance's filet was better taste-wise, but he had the same boring vegetables.

Anyway, I don't think we will be back. I think for the price, you can do much better.
author: J S.

description: Great atmosphere.  Quaint neighborhood Italian restaurant.      Very romantic.   Really enjoyed the gnocchi.    Nice wine selection.
author: Nick H.

description:
It was our 5th year anniversary dinner.
I must say that everything was just perfect for us.
Especially there was a nice low key waitress.

When you have a good mannered wait staff, you are just pleased.

But there was something, small things, it was not the big of deal, but,
My gf ordered a grilled steak, medium rare,
the steak was nice, thick and perfect medium rare, but sesame seeds stuck around the meat and we tasted Shoyu flavor.
Asian fusion steak? I don't know.

When I have a nice thick steak,
I'd rather have a grilled steak with just salt and pepper.

Grilled asparagus was thin kind and a bit burned.
I'd rather like thick asparagus for grill.
I like thin asparagus boiled, but not over cooked.
I like my gf''s grilled asparagus, a lot better.

4 grilled prawns came with Chinese red hot sauce.
My pasta came with an Asian-ish large bowl which is good idea keeping pasta warm.

I thought this place is authentic Italian food but ....a bit of Asian influence, maybe?
Hey, what do I know?

I'd like to go back.
Nice, cozy, good, low key neighborhood restaurant.
We had a great dinner.
author: Nobu K.

description:
My boyfriend and I were able to get a reservation here last minute.
First of all -- incredible setting. There's a priceless view down Washington St. of the Bay Bridge. The ambiance is beautiful... soft lighting, huge windows.

We arrived a few minutes early and were seated promptly. The warm foccacia with garlic olive oil was just a glimpse of the delicious food that awaited our palates. We started with the pear, prosciutto, and mascarpone antipasto. One word: WOW! The combination of sweet and crunchy pear, salty prosciutto, creamy and tangy mascarpone was genius. It was drizzled in a light balsamic reduction.

Next, we split the ceasar which was huge. It was topped off with delicious authentic parmiggiano reggiano.

For the main course, my boyfriend had the lobster and crab ravioli topped with a lobster bisque sauce. It was delightful and very fresh. I had the artichoke and bell pepper risotto. It was just the perfect consistency, not too mushy -- slightly al dente. The flavor was excellent as well, not too rich, and it had just the slightest hint of peppery heat.

Next was the highlight of the night... As we awaited the dessert menus, the waiter arrived and announced, "this is our flourless chocolate cake" as he set it down in front of me. A bright sparkle caught my eye -- an incredible engagement ring was resting beside the slice of cake, as if it were part of the garnish! Next thing I knew, my boyfriend knelt down in front of me and proposed :) I was speechless as he slid the ring on my finger. The waiter immediately came by with generously-sized glasses of Veuve Cliquot on the house ($16 per glass). Everyone in the restaurant congratulated us, it was such a beautiful moment! (The cake was great too, by the way..)

The waiter gave us plenty of time to finish up, although we couldn't wait to call all our friends. What a treat! We will hold Venticello dear in our hearts for years to come. The staff was wonderful overall, and assisted in the covert engagement operation so seamlessly and beautifully. :) :) :)
*********************************************************
UPDATE 06/09/06: i'm so touched that this was chosen as review of the day. this is awkward and uncomfortable to say, but the two of us actually split up a few months ago... i had considered changing the review to reflect the status quo, but venticello really deserves accolades for their amazing service and delicious cuisine. also, this was a beautiful and perfect experience, nonetheless... what's past is past! anyway, wanted to let you all know so there's no confusion.
author: Jill M.

description:
Adorable location - I love restaurants that clearly used to be homes.  We were a bit squished in to the bar area (sorry sir, I did not mean to rub all up on you that much on my way to and from the restroom), right across from the open door which was nice initially, but then got a little chilly.
The ambiance was great, the company was great, the service and food just okay.  I'd come back and give it another shot, but I wasn't blown away on my first visit.
author: Jennifer D.

description:
Unwelcoming service, crappy food.

BUT - it does live up to the promised romantic atmosphere and offers some pretty good Italian wines.
author: Jill D.

description:
Tagged onto Amy S. and her man's dinner reservations and was reminded of how I should go here more often than every 5 years! I'm not a pasta person so much, but the cesar salad and ahi tuna were well prepared and seasoned. Wine list was good and reasonably priced (god I love Stag's Leap). Panna Cotta and port were divine. 

Only drawback this night was the service. Host was great, but we nearly had to goose the spacey server to get her attention for more wine, to order, for the check--kind of nuts considering it wasn't very packed.
author: Gretchen T.

description:
I'd been meaning to eat here for about 4 years and so glad I finally did!

Why you should eat here:
- You miss the Tuscan countryside.
- You miss 'higher-end' rustic Italian food.
- You want to eat somewhere that's been going strong for 14 years, and that's owned by 6th generation San Franciscans.
- You want to get engaged. (No joke, they have tons of people getting down on the knee here.)
- You live in the hood and want a pasta and glass of wine after work. (Nice small granite bar.)

It's one of the most charming (and large) neighborhood restaurants tucked away on a hilly street in Nob Hill. Replete with a high stack wood-burning oven, and cable cars occasionally passing by.

Food-wise, it seems they've mastered tastes and textures even in the simplest dishes...  The apps were my favorite: 1) Smokey portobello mushroom cooked in the wood oven, served on soft polenta with crunchy, chopped pine nuts mixed throughout, rosemary and some tangy tomato dice.  2) Salty pancetta-wrapped succulent prawns with a very hot pepper oil/sauce.  3) Salad of sweet red & gold beets, salty capers, tangy vinaigrette, in a bitter radicchio cup. 

Lobster bisque pasta with prawns was a creamy, garlicky delight.  Tiramisu was allegedly good, but I don't like that mushy blobby dessert anyway, so can't rate that one...

Great meal.  The Clos du Val Chardonnay is nice and smokey, and goes great with all their dishes that come out of the wood oven.
author: Melanie C.

description: Gummy pasta. Uninspiring menu. Not awful not good.
author: robbie l.

description: I didn't go on on Valentines day and really loved it!  Have been several times, it's very cute and the trams go right by.  Nice food and atmosphere.
author: Harriet P.

description:
Tucked on the corner of Clay and Taylor- Venticello looked like a Tuscan estate seated majestically atop the hill.  It was subtly lighted  by candles complete with wood burning fireplace (brick oven)that added to its alluring ambiance. 

I arrived a little early to give them a special request on behalf of celebrating my friend's new job.  Given that it was busy night (we were seated after a 30 minute wait), Daniel (Manager) welcomed the added request and even comped my champagne and friend's beer to remedy the long wait.  What a great way to start the celebration ! :-)

Our waiter was attentive and easily accommodated a seating change due to the proximity to the fireplace (quite warm). The giant open door windows gave a fantastic view of the Bay Bridge and also welcomed the warm gentle breeze inside.

I checked their menu to see if they offered light dishes given the warm week we've been having.  I found that they had a few dishes which were not too heavy and was confident that my health conscious friend would find a desirable meal.

We shared the appetizer Prosciutto E Pere Con Mascarpone- this was  delightful just enough to whet both our appetites.  The pear was softly blanched and added sweetness to the lightly salted prosciutto ham.

My friend ordered the Filetto Di Sogliola- two generous  filet of Petrale Sole pan fried to perfection, complimented by the white wine sauce seasoned with capers and cracked pepper.  The polenta cake was just enough to make this a perfect comfort food on a warm evening.  I was excited to try the Gnocchi al Funghi ( Im making a list of the best ones in the city) and I would probably give this one 3 stars.  The gold nuggets were dense and too thick in nature- I was longing for the pillowy, velvety texture but these did not measure up( I think it was overcooked).  Its sauce was just a tad salty for my taste and the mushroom pieces didn't add complexity to the creamy nature of this flavoring.

There are others dishes I would like to try the next time I visit:-  the Risotto with Tiger Prawns, the Ravioli and Scalopine!  Perhaps on a cold rainy day ;-)

PS- The tiramisu congratulatory cake arrived complete with our waiter's well wishes (complimentary  as well!).  There is nothing more satisfying than having a meal complete with friendly service and attention to detail.  Thank you for your wonderful service!
author: Arissa C.

description:
Beautiful little italian restaurant in Nob Hill. The good and the bad part about this place was that it was almost identical to a typical restaurant in a small town in Italy. 

The service was mind-boggling slow...we had a reservation for 7:30 and weren't seated  until 8. Once we were seated it took forever for our food to actually materialize. They weren't very attentive with drinks and we had to flag them down just to get a glass of wine. But again, typical Euro-style service. 

The pasta here is made in house and our Seafood pasta special was amazing...perfectly cooked. The procuitto appetizer was pretty good, nothing too amazing. Overall the food was very tasty but the time we had to wait for it muddled the total experience.
author: Jane K.

description:
Overall, I give this place a rating of 4. It's not the greatest Italian I have ever tasted, but it is a very enjoyable Italian meal in comparison to its Italian competition in the area. Really, I would give the food a 3 1/2 average, with some individual dishes deserving a 4 1/2. The wine list is a pretty good value. 

But really, here the winning component is the ambiance. It is a really charming little establishment on Taylor and Washington. A wood burning oven extends a warmth around the room, while the cable car rings by.  Long-established server and sommerlier Tim is a wonderful guy who really knows his stuff and just will make your night a great experience.
author: Anna S.

description:
I went here with my girlfriend for Valentine's Day prix fixe, $85pp. ostensibly four course. more on that in a moment.

Valet parking felt more than necessary. No parking in the area, it seemed, and the rain curbed my enthusiasm for further searching.

We walk in, choose a table on the entrance level (entrance is located higher up along the slope that the restaurant spans). Rose petals are strewn over white tablecloth, nice touch.

Wines are picked. Menu matched what they had on their site a month ago. Girlfriend still not too happy with the choices, but I have faith in Yelp and The Four-Star Cutoff (which I still maintain would make an awesome band name).

We order.

Valentine's Day destroys food, it seems. I'll recount the carnage course by pseudo-course.

Appetizers:  Lobster bisque too salty for the lady, my salmon carpaccio seemed like it was a no-prep dish, just a few things tossed onto a plate alongside the salmon. No flavors mixing in glorious dance, no subtle twisting of colors in my minds eye (think Ratatouille); I am disappointed. My lady is frowning, because she can and does make food better than this. I am frowning because she is frowning.

First entree: The root of my gripe with their "four-course" label, this is barely another appetizer. I know it is technically still a course, but I still feel the urge to protest that fact. Larger than an amuse-bouche, I suppose, but the comparison is worth a mention.
Anyhow, a choice between cheese ravioli and gnocchi. I go ravioli, lady takes the gnocchi. Ends up being four decent-tasting pieces of ravioli and a small pile of some overcooked, oversalted gnocchi. Possibly the best food of the evening--or more correctly, the least terrible.

Second entree: The lady gets chicken marsala, I the New York steak. Chicken is oversalted. I know everything my girlfriend has gotten is labeled as too salty, I should add that her taste runs towards the lighter side of salt, but it was salty even for me.
Steak had some butter-ish sauce on top of it. Crusted on top. I was not happy. i kept thinking of heat lamps and warming drawers. And tureens of mushroom gravy.
The steak was also weirdly tough; again, my feeling is that overcooking was involved.

Dessert: Cheesecake was bad. Other thing was bad. We were ready to leave.

All this for $250.
I am not coming back.
With respect to food, I would have preferred pho, Taco Bell, or otherwise. I must emphasize that this is not hyperbole. I really feel that I have derived more enjoyment from a large bowl of #15 pho (rare steak and tripe, in case the number system doesn't translate).
With respect to price, I would go to Gary Danko instead.

I don't like to give one-star reviews. They seem to indicate either unnecessary anger at being snubbed by the employees, or an intentional snubbing of the establishment. But here, I cannot think of much to redeem this place, and unfortunately, not enough to justify a second star. I understand that V. Day is difficult (easy comparison to D-Day), but isn't that what a selective prix-fixe menu--pardon this--fixes? Last year's restaurant managed an excellent meal. The year before was fine, too. Both of those meals cost less than $50 per person. Why can't this highly-rated, centrally-located restaurant do at least as well?
And why am I strongly considering doing dinners on the day before AND the day after Valentine's Day, instead of the day itself? It really sounds like a good idea at this point.

I will be actively dissuading friends and family from dining at this restaurant. So actively dissuasive will I be, that I will suggest alternatives, like the aforementioned Gary Danko, or even Rutherford Grill up near Napa.
author: David H.

description: Excellent food from appetizer to several mains through a variety of dolce and an excellent $40 bottle of red wine.  My only complaints are that there were a few flies around and our server's appearance - too many facial piercings and a somewhat sour expression.  With a professional server this would have been a 5-star review.
author: Mizu H.

description: This place was great! Small but amazing food! The minestrone soup was the best I have ever had and the pear pizza was amazing!!!
author: Mia B.

description:
Not sure how to give less than 1 star. Where do I begin?   I have just moved back to SF for business from my native Terni in central Italia. A work colleague of mine asked me to join him for a dinner at Venticello. As a
we entered everything seemed very nice. Then we sat down and disaster began, first thing we both saw was a mouse or rat running accross the dining room under our table. First we laughed and then we were a little nervous. Then the food began to arrive.  Oh my, really???  this is NOT Italian food in any way , everything over salted with 70's presentations. This place is lost in 1976 food.  We start with carpaccio which was flavorless and the arugula was slimy and yellow, we left it behind. I was liking some pasta so I ordered the Carbonara which is a regional dish in my native area. Terrible, inedible, salty and undercooked. My friend had a filet that was described as pancetta wrapped with guanchale...whats guanchale...I think the word they were looking for was "guanciale".....also way too salty and the presentaion looked like a 10 year old made it. Plenty oferrors in grammar on the menu not to say. Sorry, but for these prices I would surely hope there is better Italian food than this in SF, such an international city with good food reputaion.  I was embarrased for this place.  $150 fo ra terrible experience, i can eat in any trattoria in my town for 30 or 40 euros and have food that is 100 times better.  I guess the mice eat ok.  Schifoso.!!!!!  Vergogna!!!!!   Save your money and cook at home , it will be better.!!!!!!
author: Luca C.

description:
In the big scheme of things this place is OK, and in San Francisco, OK does not cut it. In contrast to A16, Delphina or countless other Italian restaurants this place is not very good at all. First off we were welcomed by an unfriendly man behind the bar in a giant canary yellow shirt, note to the world; if you are a really big man, canary yellow is not your color, regardless, he was cold, brusque and left us to our nice, but wholly discombobulated waitress. 

Upon sitting and ordering, our underwhelming dining experience commenced. Our Manhattan's were extremely watered down, and the food was over-seasoned, poorly presented and contrived at best, though the mashed potatoes were great and the food inoffensive, but I should never be saying that the mashed potatoes were the highlight of a fairly pricy dinner. The wine list is a total joke, I mean, total joke, no attempt was made to even remotely enter into the San Francisco mindset of wine, instead we had a mediocre bottle of Mt. Veeder Cab, which is sad when it's the best thing on a list. Also, the decor and atmosphere were not 'romantic' as described, but really cheesy and dated. I've had much worse meals, but would not recommend this place to others.
author: brant f.

description:
There is something to be said for a great space, I don't know why, but I really love this place. I wanted to live there - wierd? Maybe, but if the chef comes with the place, you would pay rent there as well. The restaurant is a beautiful, open two-storied room with high ceilings and an open, welcoming feel. 

We had an early meal on a Saturday evening, but the place filled up very fast. The home made squash soup was as authentic as the wait staff. My rack of lamb wasn't the best I'd had in my life, but it was still way above average. The pasta, however, is rave worthy. 

The best part about it is it's not on the main drag - feels nice and out of the way. Definitely 2 thumbs up from a serious Italian food lover.  Still on the quest to determine the best in SF. And I am committed to trying each and every one until I'm completely sure.
author: Lindsey B.

description: Great, great place! Had dinner 12/23 with the BF and was amazed by the service and food. I'd been before but with a large group (limited menu, rushed service). This time, we could not have had a nicer time. Service was paced perfectly, all were very friendly, suggestions were great. Food was absolutely perfect. Taste was amazing, portions were perfect. All in all, it was one of the most satisfying dining experiences I've had in the City (and I've been to all the "great" restaurants). Trek up Nob Hill and have dinner here. You will not be disappointed. Suggestion....have a pre dinner drink at The Big Four in Huntington Hotel.
author: Brian L.

description: Excellent food and very romantic. Not required but nicer dress is a plus.
author: Colt Y.

description: What a super find!!  I ate here for the first time tonight, and the host was so kind and accommodating.  We hadn't made a reservation (on a Saturday night - which seemed to perplex the host), but he made room for us and we were seated relatively quickly...  I had the mushroom gnocchi to start....which is huge.  I was surprised by how large the portions are...  And then I had the lamb tenderloin.  If only I had room for dessert, then I would've definitely had the strawberry cheesecake...  The only drawback is that it is on the pricey side...but I am excited to go back to this neighborhood spot...
author: Wendy L.

description: came here for a fancy date dinner with my partner. it is definitely a romantic place, though not gauche or cheesy in anyway. great ambiance for small family dinners or anniversary/celebratory dates, etc. our server was fantastic. the dinner was pricey, but worth every penny. we ordered an appetizer and a salad to share (beef carpacio, beet salad), followed by (1) gnocchi with funghi (best gnocchi in white sauce i've had); (2) a fettucine with [spicy] sausage; and a fantastic sangiovese wine from acorn winery. SUPER delicious, will definitely come back.
author: Winnie T.

description:
Great service- it was RAGING hot last night and we were unfortunately upstairs so the firecracker prawns were reeeeeally hot!  I had the sole, and am bummed I didnt get the carbonara like my dad... I love a good fresh pasta!!!  Their pinot by the glass really was excellent like the waiter said- decent glass size too.  Stepmom got the veal she said it was excellent, and it was a lot of food.  Boyfriend got the caesar and then the ahi- he had no complaints!
Heres how cool they are tho - my dad left his credit card and they called the house not 5 mins after we walked thru the door, so he walked back and got it!!  Sooo sweet of them, saved a pain in the hind!
author: Catherine R.

description:
What can I say, this place is amazing. I've been here twice so far, and will continue to be going back. I took my girlfriend here for her birthday and another special occasion and it couldn't have been better. The atmosphere is really romantic and is in a very nice neighborhood so if after dinner you want to take a walk it has some great views. 
To get to the food the first time I went I got the Veal Scallopine... it was extremely delicious and tender.  For the second time I went I got the Penne Bolognese, it was a special at the time, and I must say it was the best Bolognese It was just soooooo amazing once it hit you lips!
author: James H.

description: Whoever rated this place "romantic" must live in constant chaos!  We dined here on a Saturday night and found the place noisy and the service nearly nonexistent. The food was delicious but couldn't compensate for the unpleasant ambiance and poor service.
author: Suzanne S.

description: We are from out of town and selected this restaurant by researching on the internet. Went there for a birthday and were not disappointed. Our reserved table was ready for us when we arrived.. We did not have to wait even though it was Saturday night. We were immediately made to feel welcome here. The food was of the highest quality and the service was super--the best. Very friendly place. Don't miss the tiramisu.
author: R A.

description:
i had a wonderful dinner here with my mother the other night when the wait at Nob Hill Cafe was too long, and boy were we glad we kept walking.  This place has a really nice, rustic feeling lower dining area, and we loved the open wood-burning oven and interesting detail work/antique-like, yet tasteful decor.  But more importantly, everything we ate was delicious.

We started w/ a daily special salad of fresh mozzarella, tomatoes, and basil over arugula with a sundried tomato vinaigrette (a nice spin on the classic caprese).  I don't even like sundried tomatoes, but I found the dressing delicious and the ingredients were impressively fresh.  

My mother ordered the herb and goat cheese ravioli in a tomato, basil, garlic sauce.  As much as I love ravioli, I usually shy away from ordering anything resembling marinara sauce when at a restaurant because it seems like something I can make just as easily at home, but I have to say the pasta certainly was delicious (they make it themselves) and the sauce certainly did not come from a jar.  

I had the grilled lamb tenderloins (i adore lamb), and they cooked it perfectly(i.e. rare...I hate getting overcooked meat).  I also was expecting little circular medallions, but they cut it more in a vertical from the tenderloin, which was interesting and thus made for larger portions.  Plus the mashed potatoes and mushroom chianti sauce were divine.  Even my mother who has sworn off lamb b/c she can't stand the taste anymore actually enjoyed a bite of mine.  

Dessert of fresh berries in custard cream served in a martini glass was a lovely cap on the evening.  

The waiter was very friendly and attentive (i loved the big water glasses because I go through water in restaurants like nobody's business).  I also heard our waiter telling the table next to us that they've been in sf for decades now, before the small-plate craze became popular, so they still like to serve large hearty portions.  

Yes, this is a nicer restaurant for slightly more special occasions if you're on a budget, but the food is definitely top notch, the ingredients fresh, and the atmosphere comforting and friendly.
author: Anne Marie B.

description:
Don't go here if you expect your reservation to be honored.  Do. Not.  I went to a lot of trouble to get a res for my party of six for last Sunday 12 December----- including visiting the place.    Everyone said, no problem.  When I arrived with my party I was told  it would have been (had we stayed) a 30 minute or more wait.  The salt on the wound?  

The smart-ass, egotistical, "too-bad-just-deal"  'tude of maitre d' "Alessandro".   When I complained my guests were standing in a crowded doorway, half-in, half-out of the buiding, he chose the lofty, condescending approach, essentially saying, "grow-up man, this is the Big City" ----and this to an SF native who first visited this place long before he was hired.   His coolest move, though:  boasting, as if he were proud, "you're lucky, last night we were running 90 minutes behind...."   

One of my guests, who lives two blocks away, advised he "never goes there" since their res system is worthless.

To be fair, in years past, I have gone in early and had a very good meal with courteous service.    That's why I went to the trouble to rebook my Sunday crew.  

I'm told the same people own this place who own Nob Hill Cafe.   At least at NHC, they TELL you they don't take reservations.

Alessandro and his crew might want to consider a new and different approach:  stop trying to churn tables with people waiting around for their phantom res to come up and just take FEWER reservations.     They may also want to work something else:  politesse........
author: bob g.

description:
I'm torn on this one....there is so much good Italian food in San Francisco and while this place didn't rank highest for me on food, I really did appreciate the ambiance and service. 

Let me begin by saying that my bf and I visited Venticello on one of the warmest evenings of the year and were unfortunately seated next to the pizza oven. But even that didn't bring my experience down because just as quickly, I was delivered a perfect, icy cold Ketel One martini and was immediately pacified. 

Our food server was on his game - professional and attentive but not overbearing. The fresh foccacia and garlic olive oil was to die for...but then the heirloom tomato salad with fresh mozzarella left a little to be desired. My opinion is that the sun dried tomato vinaigrette was too heavy for the salad but it's hard to identify what went wrong there. I then proceeded to have the fresh (albeit seared) sushi grade ahi tuna. The prob there is that fresh sushi grade tuna need not be seared and smothered in a creamy caper sauce. It tasted pretty good but it was much heavier than I'd anticipated as a result of the sauce. My bf had the sirloin and only told me the next day that the first half of the dish was delicious and the second half was tough as shoe leather. He's never one to stay quiet so I'm not sure why he didn't send it back. 

We skipped dessert in lieu of picking up Swensen's on Union but the dessert menu did look interesting.... 

I'd go again but probably wouldn't cross town to do it.
author: Carrie S.

description:
I almost gave this place 4 stars simply because it is always ridiculously warm here, BUT the food is so good I had to go 5.

I live in the neighborhood and frequent this place for a quick bowl of pasta (anything is great) and glass of wine.  Random, but they also have this delicious Beet salad served in a cup of radicchio (sp?).  Fettucine w/ sausage -- yum...

They also have a bar that you can sit at should you be dining on your own :(
author: John R.

description: Ok so we didn't eat there (that's why I'm not giving 5 stars) BUT we were running late and they held our table for us.  We did have yummy dessert and a great bottle of wine. The atmosphere is quintessential SF. Very romantic and cozy.  Staff was VERY awesome.  Got there via cable car as well which was great.
author: Alyssa O.

description:
Enjoyed a lovely evening here. It looked like there were a lot of couples enjoying a date night. Venticello also proved a perfect place to host out of town colleagues traveling from Boston and London. It felt like a quintessential "SF" restaurant in being   "on a hill, hosting a view of the bay bridge from the entrance, great for cable car spotting etc.," but more importantly felt very off the beaten path. 

I arrived early and was welcomed by the lovely bartender who made sure I had a drink and bread to nibble on immediately. 

The pasta with bolognese was delicious, although I'll warn very rich/heavy even for a bolognese fan.
author: Emily L.

description:
My experience with Venticelli Ristorante was quite magical. We were turned away at the door by a straight forward, fast talkin gentleman. He easily dismissed our no reservation request for a table of four..but then commented on how fashionable I looked...and gave us a table quite promptly. Daniel, the manager/owner?, turned out to be quite the gentleman and offered only the best service to our table. 

The atmosphere was lovely and romantic..dimly lit...with a view of a partial bay bridge. The mirrors made the quaint place seem much larger and the warm tones added comfort to the eatery.

I ordered the gniocchi with mushrooms and gorgonzola cheese. It was rich in flavor and I enjoyed each bite as much as the last. The house bread with plve oil, eggplant wraps, lamp, and fish were all excellent as well. Some of the best Italian food I've ever eaten!!

So get dressed up! Go eat there! Tell Daniel hello! And them promptly and quickly follow me on Twitter. "jaelove42187"
author: Jason L.

description:
Eating at Venticello reminded me of my youthful experiences with the confounding Wonderbra: at first, you are very interested, attracted, aroused even, but once the clasp comes undone, you are left to wonder, soggily, where all the fun has disappeared to.

Amanda F. and I took a couple of our friends to what seemed like a gem of a neighborhood restaurant right in our backyard.  We've walked by it many times on our Sunday morning excursions and have always commented on its quaint appearance and convenient location.  The menu looked thoughtful and carried the distinction of being Michelin-rated as a great value.

We entered the restaurant and were all suitably impressed by the inviting elegance of the place: dark wood panelings, white Christmas lighting throughout, comfortable seating and a surprisingly good lounge music mix floating in the background of quiet chatter and tinkling dishes.

Disappointingly, we were seated in the front upstairs bar area, Venticello's low-rent district to be sure.  It certainly lacked the quaint appeal of the downstairs seating area.

However, service was prompt and formal, which I found to be charming.  Whoever that tall, dark Italian man was, he seemed to take the business of food service as a point of pride, national pride even, like Germans with their beer or the French with their prostitutes.

Predicably, the Wonderbra moment came once the dishes were cleared and before I had a look at the check.  It was then I realized that I'd been hoodwinked by the waiter's poor English and some old Christmas lights.  The food was just not that good.  I mean, I didn't feel the need to vomit, and score my tongue with the crushed dried remains of Arabian scorpions.  But my oven-fired pizza and veal scallopinis moved my heart not to roar a great, manly Whitmanian "Yawp!" but rather emit a meager "Meh."

That's it, Venticello, you breaker of romantic teenage hearts, you conjuror of phantasms, you lusty fun-slayer!  When I realized that those mountains were molehills, that that rack was more engineering than genetics, when the chips were down and the great tits were gone, my high school nightmare recurred in full blown digital clarity: I was left paying too much for the pleasure, and there was no chance in hell that she was going to get me off.
author: Donny S.

description: We had dinner at Venticello last night (Friday, January 16) as part of a large group that had been prearranged for several weeks.  Reservations were at 8:45 p.m.  We all arrived at time, but the prior seated party occupied one of our tables for over half an hour, delaying our seating for almost 45 minutes. (They were just sitting there after having paid their bill chatting.)  Because our party was so large the restaurant requested we have a preset menu with limited items, which was reasonable.  My choice was supposed to be a chicory salad with persimmons, cioppinio, and a flourless chocolate cake for dessert.  The salad turned out be a different salad, made with radicchio, with no chicory and no persimmons.  It was ok, but not anything special.  The cioppino was ok, but not great.  My husband had the steak and said it was good, but several diners complained the steaks were over cooked.  The best part of the meal was the dessert.  The chocolate cake was delicious, and the alternative option, tiramisu as also delicious.  Given the number of fantastic restaurants in San Francisco, I see absolutely no reason to return.
author: Liz B.

description:
Nice dating ambiance, just try not to get stuck upstairs otherwise you end up getting the draft from folks coming and going (for some reason I remembered there isn't a spring to keep the door closed).

Pastas are great.  4.5 stars for fresh pasta but the one complaint I have are the sauces are loaded with butter and creams.  This invariably is why the pasta tastes so good.

Antipasti and secondis were about 3 stars.  Nothing really special.  There are some affordable bottles of wine under $50.  This is a good date place, just order the pasta tho.  A bit on the spendy side for pasta tho around 17-20, but it's so filling and tasty.

One other thing - the place has valet parking, which is huge plus given the neighborhood.  It's reasonable - I believe $10.
author: J L.

description: Fail. This restaurant doesn't know how to honor reservations. We waited 30 minutes past our reservation and were then offered a crappy table by the door. Boo.
author: Mark S.

description:
Oh.  Oh, my.

How we've managed to overlook Venticello, which we can see from our front window, is beyond me.  We ate here once shortly after we moved here two years ago and only made it back this evening.

This was some serious, rustic Italian cuisine.

The table bread was even that good, served with a side of garlic olive oil.  If this bread isn't baked fresh here, then someone please let me know where they get it, 'cause it's that good.

The wife raved about her Venticello salad--baby lettuce in a honey mustard dressing with toasted walnuts and Gorgonzola cheese.  These are some of her favorite things.

I opted for the Barbabietola salad, an earthy, fresh mix of roasted beets, tomatoes, and arugula, topped with just the right amount of a tarragon caper vinaigrette, all contained in a nice bowl of radicchio.  Uh, huh.

We shared a couple of entrees.  The spaghetti carbonara was the best I've had, hands down.  The pancetta was cooked down to just-this-side-of-crispy perfection.  The creamy sauce was seasoned to a perfect balance of zesty/rich.  I'll probably have dreams about this dish.

The grilled pork tenderloin medallions in a balsamic rum syrup was another winner.  The syrup makes the dish shine.

We were too sated to even attempt dessert, all of which sounded delectable.

The service was excellent, always attentive, but never intrusive.  The space is a bit cramped, but when you're in a state of culinary bliss, you tend not to notice.

We'll be making Venticello a member of our family.
author: Daryl E.

description:
I know people rave about this place, but I just wasn't feeling it.  It is fairly standard italian fare, but VERY expensive for what you get - it's like the average italian joint on the corner of NYC that you can get your take out from when you are feeling lazy.  This is definitely the place you take your parents to - it's got good ambience, not too loud, but most importantly they can foot the bill!

If you are willing to deal with the wait and are OK with something much more low key, go to nob hill cafe which is a block away.  

I live right across the street - I feel like the best thing about Venticello is the fact that it is a great place to catch a cab from because of all the customers that are getting dropped off.
author: Jessica W.

description:
We discovered Venticello 5-6 years ago and it has become our benchmark reservation any time we visit San Francisco. It has NEVER disappointed.

Venticello is in a wonderful neighborhood Nob Hill location. It's somewhat small, but very cozy with a huge wood burning oven in the middle. The restaurant is one room, built on several tiers. The best tables are on the lower level by the front windows. Try to get the corner window table.

The menu offers a mix of Italian regional specialties -- not too many items, just enough. Salads, pasta courses, main courses -- just enough selections to find what you prefer.

The wine list is similar -- enough to find something you'll like, but not too much to confuse you. For example, during our recent visit there were 3-4 Italian reds in the $30s. We settled on a Vino Nobile di Montepulciano for just $34.

Service is generally very good. This past trip was a best ever. We arrived 10-15 minutes ahead of our reservation and were seated immediately. Service was attentive and informative. Every course was perfectly timed. And we left with a bill under $100 for two, even with wine.

Venticello is a winner!
author: Tom K.

description:
I've walked by this restaurant several times on my way to Nob Hill cafe. I finally stepped in to try it. At first it seemed promising. We called to make a reservation, none were really available till 8:30. We mentioned how close we lived and she said we could come in at 6 as long as we were out by 8. It was nice that they could fit us in, but it was sort of weird that they gave us an end time.

So we arrived and all looked good. We were seated...and then we waited...and waited...and waited. No one came to wait on us. The restaurant was by no means full or busy. We sat there and watched the hostess and another waitor chat. No bus boy, no water, no bread...NOTHING. Another couple was then seated after us and waited on before us. Sorry, but a little OCD about things going in order.

Once we were waited on we ordered. The wine was excellent. I'm sorry but the food was only average in my book. I got the risotto with prawns and it greatly lacked flavor. I don't know if they forgot the seasoning or what was going on, but the entire meal I felt like something was missing. My boyfriend for the sole, which was good, but the lemon and caper flavors were beyond overpowering. He was overseasoned, and was under.

The environment was very cute and charming, but if you have trouble reading in low light bring a flashlight. This place could use a few extra candles. I had to hold a candle to my menu, and it was still difficult to read.

I'm always willing to give a place a second chance, so I will go back.

A few tips: 
 - Make reservation
 - Request to sit downstairs. If you sit upstairs you will constantly get a draft from the door.
 - They do have valet, which is nice.
author: Aubrey W.

description:
I have eaten at this restaurant more times than I can remember (dozens) and it remains to be the perfect place for great food, great wine and great atmosphere.

The entrees are reasonably priced and the specials are always worth choosing.

The staff is congenial and professional.

The atmoshpere is cozy, warm there is not a bad seat in the house (except for right in front of the front door.

If you are waiting, the small bar is an nice place to have a glass of wine.

The location offers a stunning view of the bay and Bay Bridge sitting on the corner of Washington and Taylor.

The cable car rolls by right out front.

Take a date or visiting friends here and you will be a hero.
author: brad o.

description: My parents and sister came up for the weekend and they all love Italian so my honey and I brought them here for dinner here Saturday night - what a major BUST! Here are my gripes: 1 - Even though I made a reservation, we were still seated upstairs by the crowded bar next to the bar stools. 2 - The waiter was surly (young, tall, brunette, Italian guy). 3 - The spaghetti carbonara and fettuccine salsiccia were so salty. 4 - The pork tenderloin was dry and overcooked. 5 - The busboy kept asking if we were finished trying to rush us out. It was so noisy, we had to shout to have a conversation. I rarely give restaurants 1 star, but we were all very disappointed. We will not be returning.
author: Kevin C.

description:
Love Love Love....this place!!

My boyfriend discovered Venticello over the summer, trying to find a small, romantic Italian restaurant to take me for my birthday. Since that day I've been hooked!!

The restaurant itself is very warm and cozy. At the top of the hill you have great views and can even catch the trolley after dinner. There are to levels to Venticello, an upper level with small bar and a lower level where most of the seating is. Also a wood oven for cooking delicious pizzas. I recommend making reservations and asking to sit on the lower level, its much nicer.

Now to the good part. Venticello's food is just great. their pastas are amazing, I have two favorites the gnocchi and the carbonara. Great salads and pizza as well. 

Overall I just love this place, very romantic and worth the trip to the city. YUM!
author: chistine g.

description: Venticello is simply a neighborhood gem. Great location...romantic yet lively environment.....which I know is contrary...but you have to check it out and see for yourself. The host is very charming and we had a nice rapport going the entire evening. My GF was dressed to the nines and he was appreciative of her effort and gave us a great table. The service was attentive...the food was good, not great...the ambiance was perfect for a late dinner. Would absolutely return.
author: Joe F.

description:
One of our party got an affogato here that was amazing.  The rest of the meal was good.  Don't know if I would come again though, because there are a lot of better restaurants in the city.

Addition: The reviewer below me personally messaged me to insult my review b/c he didn't agree with my review.  Big deal - we all have different taste.  So I am just going to respond to his review:

"Good italian food is about loving life not just dinner... Doing Italian right is about optimizing the pleasure quotient."
 - That goes for more than just Italian food.   Italians are DEFINITELY not the only culture that believe the dining experience is a time to sit back, relax, socialize, and enjoy.  Practically everywhere in Europe and parts of Asia are like this.  With that said, there are tons of other restaurants even just on my street with a far warmer and more sociable environment than this place.  This comment sounds like it could come from a pretentious "I've traveled/lived in Italy/know Italians and know about Italian culture thus my opinion matters more than yours" type person.  I hate to break it to you, but I'm sure a lot of people have done at least one of those things as well, including myself.  

I liked the set-up at Venticello, but I did not find it to be one my favourite restaurant ambiances in San Francisco.  I was there with some friends, and it was quiet and dead  ( where's the passion mentioned in the review below? It wasn't there when I was eating my dinner).  Good company can make a restaurant seem far more enjoyable, but I do not think that the people you bring to the restaurant should be part of the review of the restaurant (otherwise I might as well give 5 stars to every restaurant I bring my friends to).  So I'm not going to factor that into my review.  

My review was based on what I found the restaurant itself to be - The food and the set-up are good, but I've experienced far better in SF.  If it was cheaper, I'd give it one more star.  But, for the prices, I could easily find a restaurant with better food, a better atmosphere, and more creativity.
author: Jen Z.

description:
A good neighborhood place for sure, If I lived near by I would be there all the damn time. This place isn't trip worthy, but since my grandparents live right down the street, I go there semi-often. 
The food never fails to dissapoint, the waiters and waitresses are pleasant, and the view  (if your sitting at the right table) is amazing. 

Last time I was there I had the proscutto wrapped shrimp with some extremely fiery dipping sauce,  and the dipping sauce I kept for the rest of the meal to adorn everything else I got. It was great.
Then I had some braised spare ribs, which I admittedly am a spare rib  addict, and they were good, not le colonial good, but they were good.
Dessert ....... i forgot what I had for dessert, so yea,,, forgettable I guess.

Over all a great local joint that I would go to more if I lived closer.
author: John S.

description:
Italiana rustica!! 

This place has a very beautiful interior, with a cozy fireplace, and beautiful plates. Super mellow, dressy, atmosphere. Wonderful service! rsrvtns suggested.

The soft herb-y italian bread and delicious herb and garlic infused oil is AMAZING. The imported italian wine is A+!

I had the herb ravioli, and it was al-dente for sure. They make pasta in house, as you will see noted on the menu. The marinara was tangy and flavorful. They have a huge block of parmesan they grate in your face, which is beautiful. I sampled the rabbit stew, and it was... rabbit stew. It took me back... like ratatouille... to my grandfather's cooking. Appetizers were satisfying. Large portions.

It was 70 per person. Quite pricey, but we did have a bottle. I could tell the difference btw this place and the many random italian north beach places i've stumbled upon.  all around Italian is difficult to make exceptional, because its such a homey cusine, no?
author: Joanna C.

description:
Absolutely gorgeous food and service. Wine was wonderful, the appetizer was beautiful we just fel in love with this place.

SF restaurants are so much better than those in LA. Attitude free and food is always GOOD! (it's soooooooooooo hard to find decent food in LA) I had their carpaccio that just melted in my mouth. gorgeous handmade pasta, and out of world super heavenly panna cotta. I have never eaten anything that delicious!

Your money is well worth it, very romantic lighting and not-in-your-face service. But what really really makes this place is the food. See, good food sells by itself, they were full on wednesday night around 11pm!
author: Kokoro I.

description:
Came here for dinner and enjoyed every minute of it.  Its not huge with lots of sections and tables.  Perfect size and lighting.  Not too dark, and not too bright.

Service was awesome, very attentive.  

bonus points for serving Hess Allomi Vineyards (mmmm)
author: Ruben G.

description:
Whenever we have guests in town, this is the first place we think of.  We've already been there 4 times, twice before we moved here from New York, twice since.  

Decor: lush, warm room, not too big, HUGE plate glass window looking over downtown and the Bay.  Romantic without being smarmy.

Service: impeccable, approachable, attentive without being smothering.  The staff know the menu and the wine list well.

Food: ahhhh.  The foccacia appetizers and pretty much everything else was deceptively simple and stunning.  The pastas taste homemade as do the ragus, rich textures and warm foods.  Well-paired wines that won't break the bank.  Desserts...well, barely had room for them, but they were italian classics that felt re-energized and revived.  I think they took Marcella Hazan's edicts to heart: Italian is about the simplicity of the ingredients coming together through simple but loving preparation.

And with parking so bad in Nob Hill, it helps that they have valet parking.
author: Jacques P.

description: This little Italian restaurant is a must for a special occasion or small gathering of long lost family or friends. You get what you pay for at this gem of a restaurant. It was very easy to make a last minute online reservation. The restaurant itself is very cozy and personal and has a great relaxing ambiance. The tables are situated quite close to each other so be ready to join in on some conversation and possibly make some new friends. I ordered Cioppino. The food was SO fresh, especially the sea food, it all melted in my mouth. The fettucine was delicious as well, this restaurant knows how to cook an unforgettable meal. A meal with wine can range from 25-45 dollars a person.
author: Ryan S.

description:
The pancetta wrapped prawns and pancetta wrapped steak are absolutely amazing.

The service is awesome and the desserts don't disappoint. 

I would go here everyday if I could...
author: R T.

description:
We celebrated our wedding anniversary here last night.  Our overall experience met expectations.  The dining room is small, intimate and romantic with a rustic feel.  Despite 2-3 large parties of 6 the overall noise level was moderate, although it got louder as the evening wore on and the bar filled with people waiting for tables.  There seemed to be just one waiter working the downstairs dining room and while there were some pauses when we wanted to order more wine he did an effective job of attending to us.  We ordered and enjoyed the arancini and the heirloom tomato gazpacho with shrimp relish; my husband's cioppino was one of the best we've had - they didn't overdo it on the tomatoes and instead it was closer to a broth consistency with a deep concentrated flavor and tons of seafood.  My lamb shank was the big miss of the evening - it was cooked perfectly but  woefully lacking in seasoning - it really needed a good dose of salt as the gremolata served with it was not nearly enough to punch up the flavor.  The wine list is well-edited and limited to California and Italian wines, with options at all price-points.

We would definitely go back and recommend Venticello to others.
author: Paula M.
