description: Had a wonderful dinner here last week.  Everything from the greeting at the door by Daniel to the dinner was top notch.  I will definitely go back with friends for dinner.  YUMMY tiramisu...
author: Matt M.

description:
This restaurant is straight out of a movie.

It's small, cozy, serves impeccable Italian cuisine, and has a view of the Bay Bridge that, at night, is almost magical.

The bread basket is warm and soft. The wrapped shrimp appetizer is delicious, with a spicy sauce on the side that I can't get enough of. The ravioli melt in your mouth.

Prices are a bit steep, but for a special or romantic occasion, you can't beat it.
author: Adam P.

description: great place nestled in Nob Hill. Great date spot with good food. Very cozy and romantic
author: Lacy T.

description: Absolutely fabulous!!! Food and ambiance were perfect. Best meal I've had in SF in years.
author: Meghan M.

description:
My husband and I treated his younger, 20-something cousin and his girlfriend (who were visiting from out of town) to a nice dinner out in SF last night, and Venticello was highly recommended. Maybe we hit the restaurant on a bad night, but this restaurant was just not worth the money.

When dining at a restaurant in this price range, I expect quality service. I'm willing to forgive overpriced food if the service is great, but I am not willing to forgive poor service - even if the food is great - when paying higher prices. In this case, the service was awful, and some (but not all) of the food was really poor. It is just not worth the price, and I am generally a forgiving customer who tips extremely well. In this case, I won't go back.

Our server was rude. For example: as my husband ordered his food (the last of us to order), our server took his menu from his outstretched hand and walked away before the words were completely out of his mouth. There was no eye contact (it never occurred to me how rude this seems until it happened to us last night), nor were there smiles of any kind except the patronizing sort (you know what those look like). We prefer to bring our own, off-the-menu, hard-to-find bottle(s) of wine to accompany our dinners; we brought two, since there were four of us last night (and yes, we generally tip well, and on what the meal would have cost with wine ordered from the menu). The first bottle was opened and poured only after we'd been waiting for too long, and even then without a question about whether we'd like to taste first (we always say no, but we've never NOT been asked). When the salad and soup arrived, there was no offer of fresh ground pepper - although I'd seen it offered to other tables around us, and we both would have liked it. The small pre-ground/generic pepper dispenser on the table was empty. We waited to have our second bottle of wine opened, with empty glasses, for far too long. When the second bottle was finally poured, we did not receive new glasses, even though it was a different wine (cardinal sin for a restaurant purporting to have a great wine list). I suppose at least it was the same color as the first bottle. My meal was so salty (and I like salt) I couldn't eat it, but our server only asked us how our meal was in passing, walking by so quickly I couldn't grab his attention to request a change. In fact, my meal (the carbonara) made me ill. My almost-untouched bowl of pasta was taken by one of the busboys (busmen? I hate to call them boys.), without any second glance or reappearance by our server. Another one of the meals (fettuccine) was also extremely salty, although tolerable. The risotto was - shockingly - undersalted (had they dumped so much into mine they ran out?). We were left holding dessert menus for far too long, and finally gave up and ordered no dessert.

Overall, I felt we mainly annoyed our server, weren't offered appropriate service for the price we were paying, weren't offered the same service other diners were being offered, and more than half of what we ordered was total crap.

I want to emphasize that I understand that servers are underpaid, and are meant to make up their paycheck in tips. As such, I consistently tip 20%, and in fact my husband and I have been known to leave 35 - 40% for spectacular service. We are both forgiving of average food with wonderful service; in fact, we repeatedly patronize specific, very average restaurants because of the service.

Venticello offered neither excellent service nor excellent food. We still tipped about 17%, but begrudgingly. We also just left cash because our server never came back to pick up the bill...

This is overpriced and haughty, and absolutely not worth it. There are so many better places to go. Save your  money and aggravation.
author: Megan H.

description: This place was amazing. Brought a date here and she loved it, so that's a big plus.  Got reservations through yelp and we were seated immediately.  The staff were very nice and seemed pretty knowledgeable about the wines (but I don't know wines, so...).  I don't even drink wine and the waiter was able to suggest a wine that I actually liked.  My date had a the Gorgonzolla and pear, which was excellent.  Very well done.  I had the gnocchi.  Amazing dish, did not expect it to be that good.  Our cups were constantly filled and a waiter was never hard to find.  There's a view from the downstairs, but only if you get a good table, otherwise it's a bit hard to see, but the place is well decorated and there's a good ambiance.
author: Ayong G.

description:
This restaurant appears in Patricia Untermann's guide to solid restaurants, but I found it lacking for a few reasons.  The views of the Bay Bridge are best outside the restaurant.  The decor is a bit cheesy.  The restaurant is extremely loud.  The food was delicious, but how excited can one get about Italian food?  I would prefer Delfina over Venticello, for price, atmosphere, and quality of food.

BTW, people on Yelp engage in gross grade inflation.  Just because they served you dinner doesn't mean the restaurant deserves 5 stars.
author: Des Esseintes I.

description: *delicious gnocci*, okay ravioli, moist tiramisu (this dessert was complimentary as it was my boyfriend's birthday). its definitely tasty, but the romantic ambiance is really what you are paying for more than anything else (we just came back from italy so may be particularly picky at this moment in time). i don't think I will go back since there are so many good eateries in san francisco, but it was great for novelty.
author: Djamila D.

description:
This is a fabulous restaurant with striking atmosphere and amazing Italian dishes.  We ordered our food family style and just let the bowls and plates roll in as we passed them around and continuously made "mmmmmm" sounds as each taste of something new somehow topped the last.

The price is right, the staff is EXTREMELY attentive, its easy to find, they have a well thought out wine list, and they were very accommodating of our slightly larger group.  I'd recommend this place to anyone.
author: Ryan G.

description:
so i guess i like restaurants that have daily changing menus and the ability to try new items without compromising taste. not sure what happened - we ordered different items and somehow it didn't strike me as better than any other restaurant in north beach, except less cheesy decor. had the spaghetti carbonara last time with meat taken out, had fettuccine this time not realizing the sausage would be completely ground up into it. not being a meat eater i still recognized how single-textured the two pasta dishes were and striking similarity in taste. maybe b/c my pasta came out 15-20 minutes before everyone's entrees and got cold? like the descriptions of the "daily specials" (there are 2) i felt dinner was "just eeeeh".

we got: chicken marsala (i snuck in a bite, very dry), fettuccine w/fennel seed sausage, caesar salad no anchovy fillets, and little gems salad, plus eggplant appetizer (plate of melted cheese) and mushroom polenta.
author: Dee C.

description: Amazing Italian food on Nob Hill. Everything is incredible. I have brought family and clients to dinner here. It is awesome!
author: Nicholas H.

description: Neighborhood Italian place, interesting bi-level setting. Had the ravioli which came in a shocking yellow sauce (check out the photos), mediocre tasting. Proscuitto pizza and dessert weren't anything memorable. Overall an ok experience.
author: Yan M.

description:
Nice location and open space. Not too loud since not very many people can fit in there but the hardwood floors don't help at all. The waiters are too cool for school but still give excellent service. I can't comment much on the price since I got my meal for free (awesome perks of my job!) The saffron risotto was a sort of Italian paella - delicious, but the special that night - some sort of scampi spaghetti (alliteration much?) was like Japanese ramen noodles. Odd. 

Might go back, but only to steal some foccacia and garlic oil and then walk out without paying.
author: wendy p.

description: We were expecting much more.  The service was less then spectacular. The food was okay, but certainly not memorable.  Everything from the salad go the pasta were drenched with dressing and sauce.  It just seemed a bit unsophisticated.
author: Carter H.

description:
After passing this place many times and wondering out loud if it was good, I was taken here for my birthday last night.

I had one of the specials that evening: ravioli with ricotta and spinach, and a grappa lemon sauce. It was simply awesome. My only complaint was that the portion was rather small - I counted only 8 ravioli! I must have scarfed them down quickly because my lovely date was asking if I wanted to try her dish. She had the mushroom gnocchi, which was also superior! Compliments to the chief! (But add a few more of the delicious raviolis next time)

The other thing I should mention is the very close proximity of the tables. It is very, very tight in there. In fact, the man at the table next to me got up and put his jacket on and knocked over my glass of wine, spilling the contents and breaking the glass on the floor next to me. Luckily none of the red wine hit me, but I mention this as an improvement that the restaurant could make. So, this could have easily been a 5-star rating but points off for the small portion and very tight seating.
author: KEVIN M.

description:
Okay... I am biased because I live right across the street, and practically have a bar stool with my name on it. The last time I ate here was the week before Christmas; my boyfriend & I took his friends out for dinner. We had zero issues with our reservation, and honestly? I have never had to wait despite showing up on busy nights. Steven does a great job handling those who are waiting, and occasionally hops behind the bar to make one of the greatest martinis ever. My one real complaint is about the wine list: get some more exciting Italian wines BTG. The BTG offerings are rather pedestrian, and the only one I can really recommend is the Dolcetto. Why would you pour a CA Sauv Blanc at an Italian restaurant when there is Vermentino or Garganega to be had?

I will echo those reviewers who have balked at waiting in the upstairs area - it's simply awkward if there's no room at the bar because you're standing right in the way of servers coming from the downstairs area. I would definitely not recommend this as a place for larger groups either. And please don't come here if you're claustrophobic; the tables downstairs are very close together. Hello, couples - don't come here to fight!

Do come here if you are a fan of perfectly executed pasta... I have never had a bad pasta dish here but then, I don't come to an Italian restaurant to have cheese ravioli. The classic carbonara is one of the best around, and the fettucine con salsiccia has a perfectly addictive creamy spicy sausage sauce. I don't understand how you would order this dish not realizing that there is sausage in it - the sauce is "con salsiccia", they can't take the meat out! I actually wouldn't wish for larger portions; there are times I have had to get half boxed for lunch the next day. Then again, I'm not a runner, ha ;)
I have not had the caprese app (it hasn't been in season since I moved here in Sept), but I have enjoyed the radicchio cups with beets and the funghi pizza. The Caesar salad has a unique presentation with the whole romaine leaves, and the dressing is also quite tasty. The spicy prawns are good too, as they are not overwhelmingly spicy. My favorite app though, HANDS DOWN, is the carpaccio. I have never seen it "burried in veggies", the only veg as accompaniment is arugula and 3 caperberries, tops. The white truffle vinaigrette is so good I use my bread to sop up the remains - forget the garlic olive oil (although it's awesome!). I will echo the comment about some "dated" presentation as well though; the last time we were there, every entree came plated with the same tired-looking veggies: carrots and something green (broccoli?), even on the veal/prawn dish (which was otherwise great, especially the Sambuca cream).

I have never experienced any "attitude" from Alejandro. He is one of my favorite servers. Stefano and Tim also do a great job. Sometimes they are a little slow (probably taking a cig break), but they also obviously hang back when it gets a little romantic up in there. No one has ever been snotty to me about a reservation or anything else. The atmosphere can't be beat either; it's intimate and warm every night of the week. I kind of want to keep it a secret, but I also can't help recommending the place since it's so much better than the "traditional" (read: shitty tourist trap) restaurants in North Beach. Go Team Venticello!
author: Stephanie S.

description:
We just went to Venticello last night for my husband's birthday. It was wonderful! Our table was ready right when we showed up. Hearing the cable cars roll by was so lovely. Our server was very attentive and helpful. Since I am pregnant, I couldn't partake in their wine list, but our server created some special non alcoholic concoctions for me! We had the eggplant rolls and the pear and gorgonzola pizzete for appetizers. In retrospect, we probably could have shared one of those, especially the pizza. They were both divine.
 For our entrees my husband had the pork tenderloin in rum and balsamic reduction which was absolutely amazing!! I would never look at pork tenderloin on a menu and jump on it immediately, but in this case, you definitely should! I opted for the special butternut squash ravioli which was very good and fresh. I will definitely go back so I can try the rosemary lamb! Our server even brought out a slice of their tiramisu with a candle on it for his birthday. When we got the bill, our server had comped my drinks and one of my husband's glasses of wine. Happy Birthday to him! 
 An amazing meal, beautiful ambiance and wonderful service.
author: Maria C.

description:
Sigh.

I really wanted to love Venticello. I did. It's got great reviews.

But, it just didn't measure up. 

For all the variety and gourmet and creativity and service that I have come to expect in San Francisco, all I can say is that this place barely met my expectations for our $70 per person meal.

We started with a measly portion of carpaccio, which was bland and unexciting. Then we each had a measly portion of caesar, which was delicious but tiny. 

The wine was delicious, and no complaints about that. No complaints about the bread and yummy garlic-oil either. Our pastas were good - we had the shrimp scampi-like pasta and a special lobster penne. Both were really good and those were the larger portions. 

Dessert (panna cotta and the apflogato) were both pretty unremarkable. 

Not sure it was the best $150 I've spent...
author: Da J.

description: Okay....I read YELP when friends invited us here and we ordered the eggplant rolls.  They were good, not great.  My house-made pasta later was great tho.  gnocchi with Italian sausage.  So, my problems were not the food which was good.  One thing that we all realized midway thru dining were the chairs.  These awful wooden torture devices are surely in place to get you in and out.  Sounds silly?  After dessert, they asked to give them our table!  No shit!  They did offer a free drink in the bar but I found that off-putting.  I tried to have a moment of chit chat with the driven and frigid woman manager that asked us to leave, but there would be none of that.  Once we stood up she was done with us.  We don't drink so we did not take her up on the offer.  Nor will we return.  The waiter was efficient but was also ice cold even tho our friend spoke great Italian to him.  Didn't phase the automatron server.  Eeek!  to be so miserable around such good food.  pity
author: Robert J.

description: I enjoyed my first dinner here so much that I spent my next two birthday dinners at Venticello.  Really intimate, cozy atmosphere with excellent food and service.  Also love how it's tucked away from the street.
author: Jackie L.

description:
If you want romantic- this is the place.

If you want extremely great Italian food- this is the place.

If you want heavy pours of wines by the glass- this is the place.

Overall, Venticello gets all 5 stars! The service was prompt, the food was way better than I could have expected. We started with the grilled eggplant  appetizer which was served covered in bubbling cheese and absolutely tantalized the tongue. I could have ordered another portion of it for my entree and would have been deliriously happy!

Booked reservations on Open Table just a few days before and got a great table.

Beware, the high ceilings. The restaurant tends to get noisy.
author: Shannon B.

description:
My new favorite upscale Italian in the city. 
I have only dined at Venticello once, and ordered the Caprese salad as an appetizer and the Pork Tenderloin Medallions as my entree. 
I was treated to the meal so no comment on whether the price is right, but the food, views and experience was excellent.
author: Jason N.

description:
Let me just say, this place made me see taste. 

We started out with their polenta and portobello appetizer. The polenta was everything you wish it could be and more - it was soft, creamy, delicious, and not at all dry or grainy. The mushroom was cooked to perfection. 

The salad came next. We had the honey mustard, goat cheese,  and candied walnuts salad and it was equally as perfect. The honey mustard was the perfect complement and not at all overwhelming. 

I had their special that evening - it was a pocket-like pasta, filled with pear, gorgonzola and some other cheeses, in a butter-sage sauce. I had to close my eyes every bite and just sit their tasting it. Absolutely amazing.

Highly recommended, as an italian and as a food connoisseur.
author: Sally W.

description:
One of my favorite Italian restaurants in SF.  Great place for date night, and also a great place to take out of towners --  It has a great SF feel, and it usually provides them with much needed relief from the Wharf, Union Square, etc.  

I've eaten there several times and have never had a bad meal.  The fire grilled prawns as an appetizer are a must.
author: Patrick G.

description:
A nice rustic venue from which one may see the bay and the bay bridge.  I enter and wait for someone to seat me.  I wait and wait.  Eventually, a waiter condescends to seat me with barely a hello.  OK, greetings aren't a strong point.  The hostess appears a half hour after I was seated for my early dinner.  Perhaps with her there, you may have a better entry.

Caesar salad is fresh romaine, anchovies and is lightly dressed.  No croutons.  Pepper adds some zest.  A nice, refreshing way to start a meal.   A half order of fettucine in cream sauce with sausage.  A rustic, hearty plate of food.  Filling.  Nice.  Not stylish or compelling in any way. But good.  Veal saltimbocca is topped with tasteless chopped tomatoes and accompanied by mashed potatoes, squash, carrot and some sweet cabbage.  The vegetable sides seem misplaced, something you might pair with pot roast in a diner.  The veal is the real thing but there is an off taste of alcohol that was not cooked away on the plate.   Too bad.  The serving is substantial but the conception of the plate and preparation of the food was just not there. 

Go for the view.
author: David D.

description:
Went here last night with a friend for dinner.  It's a cute, comfy little place that you will need reservations in order to eat, unless you want to eat at the bar or in the bar area.  It is a bit squished, but still ok.  

Our service was excellent and on top of things.  We started with the portabello mushroom polento appetizer which was absolutely the best out of all the food.  Excellent flavor.  We each had the caesar salads which were just ok.  We shared the risotto dinner plate with scallops and shrimp.  I thought it was good, but I expected a little bit more from this place.

All in all, the place is definitely good.  I personally think there are many places in the city that outdo this place, but it is definitely worth a try if you're in the area and looking for some yummy food.
author: Kat M.

description:
Went here for the first time since everyone was raving how good the food here and the fact that the restaurant been around for a very long time.  I like the atmosphere and the decor of this place.  Very tuscany old style.  We ordered the carpaccio, grilled prawns, saffron risotto and fettucine in creamy sauce.  Carpaccio had so much vegies on top that it actually covered the entire plate with the meat burried underneath.  Those vegies made the plate a poor presentation and didn't add any flavor to the beef at all- was very blend.  The grill prawn was good and I really liked the spicy sauce which complimented the prawns in a very pleasant way.  The fettucine was ok, nothing spectacular.  It was presented in a "bowl"...which was not a pretty way to present the dish at all....makes it look like a "peasantly".  Risotto was the least favorite dish for me especially I love love risotto.  It was blend, no flavor.  The "prawns" were in fact shouldn't be called prawns cause they were quite small for that term. 

 The service was nice.  Overall, it's a very cute place.  I wanted to like it so much but unfortunately the food was a disapointment.
author: elle n.

description: This is down the street from me and I have wanted to go for a while.  Wine was fantastic and the food was wonderful.  The service felt friendly, attentive (but not too much) and real.  I liked it and will recommend it!
author: Ani N.

description:
I really enjoyed my meal here.  I will return again, made a reservation already.
Started with the antipasti, which was nice.  I liked the anchovy addition.  It was not terribly filling for 2 people, but still tasty.  
I had the special rack of lamb encrusted with mustard and pistachio.  It was 4 chops worth, very filling.  One side was an amazing sun-dried tomato cream puree.  The veggies were ok at best, would have loved something a little more inventive than zucchini.
We shared the flour-less chocolate cake - it tasted good. 
Wine list is good if not a bit small though.  It had anything I would need.

Minus 1 star for the thin pad on the chairs.  I like a softer chair to sit on at a nice restaurant.  If I were there for 20 minutes that is one thing.  But this is a 90 minute plus dinner.
author: Mike A.

description:
It's smaller than we thought so it was of much more noises that we expected.  

We split the chef salad and it was great!  Bf had the ravioli and he finished it all.  I had saffron risotto with tiger shrimps.  It was as good as expected.  

We liked the most its panna cotta, our first time experience of orange flavor mixed with mint.  It was very tasteful, soothing, refreshing, light and impressive.

This place may not be a good place for conversation unless you can manage to talk loud or even scream.  But if it has to be the case, the panna cotta could be a good comfort.
author: Ile F.

description:
Venticello... so cute, the wine great, food excellent, and the ambiance super cozy. However, the our waiter was a jerk!! He may have just been having an off night but come on when you drop $150 plus tip in dinner for 2 the service should be great. 
I loved the food and feel so much i will going back for a second try.
author: Ashley W.

description:
I'm giving this place three starts, but I considered giving it one star just to offset the sycophants. Because this place is not 5-star good. Especially not in SF. 

But not to be a hater (first), I'll start with the strong points. 

Physically: It's off the beaten path. It's small. Dare I say quaint. Also quaint in the way that they have no system to greet guests. Other than the quaintness of no check-in plan, which would only be problem upon first visit. Setting: ****

Food: We attempted to do a 3-course meal. Ordered antipasti, pasta, then main courses. We didn't do it in an incredibly douche-y way, but we let our server know our plan. The antipasti came out at scary light speed. (Like was it already plated?) Our table had five people. The shrimp app had four shrimp. Never did the server mention that fact. Sort of common practice at a decent place. Also the shrimp was small and dried out, like not cooked to order, I think. Pizza part of our first course was good. Pasta course was pretty good. Not great, but good. 
Entrees and desserts were pretty okay. Lamb was over-cooked. Chicken marsala was really good. Great sauce. Pork was okay. Nothing really inspired. 

Service: Saved it for last 'cause it was worst. The waiter clearing an expensive bottle of wine with much wine left in the bottle was a new treat. At best the service was robotic--like timely, with zero personal touch. 

End of story. It's pretty okay. The 5 star reviews on Yelp are a little bit misleading.
author: hart l.

description: We have eaten at Venticello several times.  Small groups, large groups, couples and even a single.  Every time we are treated royally.  This restaurant would be considered a neighborhood secret if the secret had not been let out.  Great food, courteous and attentive service and yes the restaurant is small;  that's part of the secret.  Make reservations, relax, enjoy the moment and have an experience that you will talk about for years to come.
author: John R.

description: I was so excited when I walked in the doors on Valentine's Day - the ambiance is beautiful, and i love the cozy feeling the restaurant embodies. We had a 7:45pm reservation and the man at the front told us it would be a minute and that 'they were just finishing up'. 15 minutes rolls around, 30 minutes rolls around, and then 45 minutes hits. Seriously? While waiting we both had a glass of wine figuring the 2 glasses of wine would be on house, right? Nope, they werent. After 45 minutes we were seated. I'm thinking 'ok, we're finally seated, cant wait to eat!' Let me preface this: we both are not picky eaters, and like to dine out at all types of restaurants - both of us were extremely less than impressed by the food - my pasta was overcooked, my boyfriend's steak was overcooked, and my fish was wayyy to salty. We didnt even want to look at dessert - which is a rare occurence for us. Also, the service was terrible :( - we had no idea where our waitress was for 45 minutes. The couple to the left of us sat down before us, but got their dinner after us. The couple to the right of us sat down after us but got their dinner and dessert before us. Clearly the kitchen was having a difficult time. For a meal costing $250 i expect the food to be outstanding and the service imppecable - it was the opposite. Unfortunately, I probably will not be coming back :(
author: Natalie W.

description: Went here with on a date, i don't know if i wasn't wearing the right cloths or maybe not the right color, but i went there before the evening rush with and literally they put me next to the door to their wine cellar not w/e the reason.  That sucked since there was about 2 other people there at the time, however if i forget that the waitress was awesome she knew the entire menu and was super friendly.  I loved that it wasn't a big menu and everything I had was amazing. Then ill also say its easily the best Italian food I've had in this city. That's why it had to have 5 stars and to the stupid host FU
author: willie l.

description: I'll spare you the boring, horrid details. Just...go to Il Fornaio or Amicis or whatever. The 16 year old serving you will have a better knowledge of wine and the presentation won't be as totally dumb. Actually...I think the presentation and food was better in the cafeteria at my grandmother's retirement home on spaghetti night. Yeah. I'd probably rather eat there.
author: Chloe N.

description: Super cozy, makes for a great date spot...delicious comforting italian food and the best aroma in the air upon entering.  Had the carpaccio (top pick of the night), gnocci al funghi, fettucini con salsiccia, and a bottle of sangiovese.  I'll be back!
author: Samantha A.

description:
We went here two years ago on my birthday. What stands out for me was the wait. We had a reservation, but waited over an hour for our table. They did comp us the two glasses of wine we had before they seated us. 

The ambiance was interesting--high ceilings, tall windows, and a wood fired oven in which they make great shrimp. The diners were mainly an older crowd. Many in their sixties or above, which might have been because it was a Sunday night.

The food was mainly good--those shrimp stand out after two years. I also remember a very sweet reduction with the bacon-wrapped steak. Not to our taste. 

It's Smart parking only, unless you want valet. We parked three blocks away and walked in the rain. 

If you live in Nob Hill, I can see this being a neighborhood place. Otherwise, make the trek to Farina, Delfina, Aperto, or zip over the bridge to Pizzaiolo.
author: Simone E.

description: What a great friggin place.  The food was the best I've had in a long long time.  The location couldn't be better, and I can walk to it if I need to.  Awesome wine, I like the Ridge Zin.  I mean what else do you want?  It's like stepping into a yacht club everytime.  Hush puppies, khaki's, sport coats with T shirts.
author: Amir B.

description: Old school.   Reminds you of a restaurant your parents might have taken you to as a kid.   But it works.   With amazing views of downtown San Francisco and a formal bi-level interior you still could feel very comfortable eating in wearing shorts.   While the menu and food presentation might be considered dated in this era of super chefs the food was very good and you won't leave hungry.    Our only complaint was the extra virgin olive oil was rancid.   We started with an heirloom tomato salad slightly overwhelmed with balsamic and a hearty grilled Portobello mushroom.   The steak was wrapped with pancetta, served in a red wine shallot sauce and very tender.    A great place to eat just before a show at the Masonic Auditorium.   They know the schedule well.
author: Roger B.

description:
We had dinner Saturday night with some old and dear friends from out of town, at their recommendation.  Dinner was fantastic; service was 
excellent; atmosphere romantic; locals mostly -- not a touristy place.
Each couple shared a salad as a starter -- we had the caesar, which I enjoyed, but the missus said was just OK.
Between us, we had the gnocchi with funghi and gorgonzola, petrale sole with white wine and butter sauce, spaghetti carbonara, and the special salmon pesto on soft polenta.  Wine list was small but varied, with a good selection in the $40 -$60 range.

We will return for sure!
author: Ned A.

description: My absolute favorite Italian restaurant in SF. Great staff and very accomodating with last minute reservations.
author: Henry F.

description: This place is number one on my San Francisco "underground' list.  Situated in quiet Nob Hill residential area, sister restaurant to Nob Hill cafe, a gem in itself.  Venticello is the perfect spot to enjoy San Francisco ambiance at it's best.  A few blocks down Taylor Street from California, call for reservation.  NOT a tourist trap, frequented by locals, nice wines, the best prawn appetizer ever, eloquent entrees, small cozy atmosphere.  Beats most everything North Beach.  Nice upscale Italian. Expect typical San Francisco  business attire; sport coats and a little sophisticated attire which pays due respect for this moderately upscale establishment.
author: Mr. Helper L.

description: Once again the Venticello experience did not disappoint. The interior of the restaurant is surprisingly intimate given that it's two levels. No trite fakey, italianish art on the walls. A place where you can hear your friends across the table (imagine). Food is solid, consistent and generous. However, biggest draw is the service. Particularly with Tim, who weaves his way through dinner with insight, humor and a warm personality. He makes Venticello special- otherwise it would just be great. He makes it wonderful.
author: Ms G.

description: Classic, cozy, very delicious. All the Italians that know good food go there. I was introduced to it by an Italian that knows his food. Date or just a dinner with a friend stay for a wile and enjoy the experience.
author: Nickolas V.

description: How did I just spend $75 for a dinner where I didn't eat or drink much??!  Cozy surroundings, liked the pancetta wrapped shrimp app, but nothing else stood out.  Our waiter also acted as though we were getting in the way of him doing something more important, although we certainly weren't high maintenance.   We ate there because it was convenient, but with so many other amazing restaurants to try in SF, I'd pass.
author: Eastbay m.

description: We had a great meal and amazing time. Casey (server) made one of the best Martini's I've had. She was very attentive and made good recommendations. All 4 of us cleaned our plates. The pear/Gorgonzola pizza is phenomenal. I would go back just for that! Two people had lamb (loved it and wasn't too lamby), one had the halibut special (cooked perfectly) and I had the ravioli special. Not my fave ravioli dish per say, but the homemade noodles were great and i would definitely try one of their regular pasta items next time. I suggest a making a reservation, as the place was packed on Saturday and all of the tables were full. It's a spot we will will become regulars at, especially the small cozy bar!
author: Erin T.

description: One of the most romantic, coziest spots in the city... A true San Francisco gem.  The staff makes you feel warm, welcome and like a part of their family.  The homemade pasta is exceptional.  I also recommend arriving early for your reservation and enjoying a glass of wine before dinner at their small bar up top.
author: Michael S.

description: I wish Yelp was around when I first went here.  I loved the food, the service.  We were in town for an off-site for work and found this to be one of the greatest finds.  I know it's unfair to judge after only one visit, but this visit has stayed with me since 2000 and that has to count for the extra star in my rating.  If it had not been for the referral we got from the really friendly staff at the Marc Hopkins hotel at the top of the hill, I wouldn't have known it was there.  I wish it well.  One of the best dining experiences in San Francisco.
author: Andy S.

description: Venticello is one of my all time favorite neighborhood restaurants in Nob Hill, SF. It has great food and a lovely ambiance. I love it's intimate settings for a small group of people or a romantic date. My favorite meal that I usually get? The Grilled Pork Tenderloins. Yummy!
author: Vanessa J.

description: I am in SFO 3 times a year and I make sure that I eat at Venticello  on every trip and they have yet to let me down...  The food is spectacular and the ambiance is equally great.  It reminds me of the restaurants in Roma.  I can't wait until I return. Ciao.
author: Scott M.

description: It's always surprising to me how SF has such generally mediocre Italian food, but Venticello stands out.  Great traditional menu, nice wine list, helpful service, and great decor make this the perfect restaurant for a romantic dinner or for an out-of-towner (the cable car runs right outside).  It's usually pretty easy to get in for a meal, and every time I'm there I see people dining solo...a true mark of a great restaurant.  And they've got valet parking which is unheard of in that area.  I've been four times and recommend it to everyone.  And I even took Noelle Q. there.
author: Geoff K.

description:
before hitting the new swank joint "le club" this was our dinner stop. 

the crowd were neighborhood regulars.  i wouldn't say that it's dressy as much as a little older and more conservative.  so my humenah humenah dress got a few raised eyebrows and smiles.

the food was simple like the rustic interior but tasty.

the staff is was attentive and friendly.  i was pressed for time for my rezzies at le club but they were very accomodating.

i sampled  the fire grilled prawns which were good.
the goat cheese ravioli was very hearty
for dessert, my dinner mate picked the tiramisu which was ok though i'll be back to try the others.  
the panna cotta and zabaione looked really good.

overall, the mood was very warm and comfortable. 
the food was like dining in someone's tuscan home with grandma's yummy fares coming out of the kitchen.
author: Anh V.

description:
cable car creaks past
beautiful setting, good food
service was dismal
author: Tyler G.

description: Just go, stretch your typical menu and challenge your imagination, take the wine recommendation and dont complain about the price.  If you are not happy, let me know and I'll join and order for you next time.  Its the perfect blend of ambiance and talent, a personal favorite for me and my family.  Rubi likes a lot
author: Porfirio R.

description:
Great place. Good prices, nice atmosphere.  Overall great experience. May have had something to do with the amount of wine consumed but hey, experience is experience!  Friendly service, too.  

We actually had a screaming child near us...and (not that I'm a child hater but...) it's a small place so i was worried that it would be a long meal.  The staff diffused the apparent injury with some ice cream in a hurry.  Although that made my girlfriend skip the menu dessert and order the same scoop of ice cream.  oh well.

Definitely would go back when I'm town!
author: Steve M.

description:
Though based in Oakland, I recently took advantage of a couple of free nights I'd accumulated through previous hotel stays for my wife and I to stay at the Mark Hopkins this past weekend. Looking for a place on Nob Hill and in the neighborhood for dinner Friday night, we booked and (despite some great reviews here on Yelp) had somewhat modest expectations for Venticello a few blocks from the hotel.  But it was great!  I had a great, crisp, light Caesar salad and my wife a radicchio salad to start.  Then she had a shrimp/scallop risotto and I a fantastic peppered tuna sauteed with some great greens on top of what I believe was a mashed potato/gorgonzola concoction.  Neither of the mains was a light dish (for those who have such preferences) but we loved them both as well as the salads.  I wouldn't want to get expectations up too high for very fine diners, but it's certainly a very nice, somewhat upscale neighborhood place.  If going, request a table in the main, downstairs area, as the small upstairs room is where people wait if a table isn't ready.

The one other respect in which I wouldn't want to raise folks' expectations is re the corner table downstairs that has what some reviewers have called a fantastic Bay view.  I'd call it a narrow view bordering on a sliver looking down the street and seeing part of the Bay Bridge.  Not bad, but as Bay views go nothing that special.
author: Stephen G.

description: Amazing Pork Tendorloin dish,  melt in your mouth Mushroom Gnocchi and just great service.  I have now gone there three times and each time it has been great.
author: Dan G.

description:
(YAWN)

snnnnnoooooorrreeeee....zzzzzzzzzzzzzzzzzzzzzzz

zzzzzzzzzzzzzzzzzzzzzzzzzzzzzzzzzzzzzzzzzz UM WHAT? 

Oh, sorry, I was asleep at the table, I forgot we were eating and decided to take a nap. 

Well excuse me, but you started it with your decision to do Xmas shopping on your blackberry at the table. 

No, I don't know if your Mom would like a new ipod shuffle?  

Let's wrestle!? 

Umph, owww!  (crash, bang). 

SHIT!!! 

Oh sorry sir, we were so bored with the food and poor service that we decided to wrestle?  That cool?  While you're here would you mind pouring our wine?  We wouldn't have to resort to such childish antics if you would actually pour the wine we brought in and get us drunk, we might even be distracted enough to give your average italian food more than two stars. 

Now if you'll excuse me, Scott here needs to feel the pain that is a cleanly executed dropped elbow.
author: Claire C.

description:
Who should go here: Residents of Nob Hill and surrounding area, or people looking for a north beach type Italian restaurant in a more quiet setting.

1 Star - Lacking/Turn Off
2 Stars - Needs Work, But fixable
3 Stars - Adequate
4 Stars - Near perfect, rough edge here or there
5 Stars - Can't get much Better

Ambience/Atmosphere: 3 Stars.  Believe it or not I was actually disappointed in the ambience/atmosphere at Venticello.  It was nice, quiet, with a bit of a romantic feel.  However, it seemed a bit forced and unnatural.  It actually seemed a little generic, and not the hole and the wall Italian place I had envisioned before going there.  This could have been some place in a mall in the midwest.  There is nothing really disappointing about it, but there are many more romantic/cosy places in the city, with much better ambience.  Very average.

Service:  2.5 stars.  Our waiter was very nice, but I felt dropped the ball throughout the meal.  One thing I hate is when waiters/waiteresses over pour wine, making you feel rushed.  Here we found ourselves pouring our own wine, because of the very infrequent visits by the help.  Also, he didn't provide much value add to the meal and definitely did not enhance the dining experience.  It wasn't bad enough where I wouldn't come back, I just felt neglected and searching for more.   This could have been luck of the draw of who was helping us, so I wouldn't make a decision on going to Venticello on my service comments.

Food: 3 stars.  The food at Venticello to me was typical North Beach Italian fair.  I was hoping for a lot more from this place given many of the glowing reviews over the years.  But to be honest it was pretty average, and most of the dishes were prepared in typical fashion and were a little bland.  Basically, nothing special.  We started off with the roasted mushrooms over polenta and the beef carpaccio.  The mushrooms were a pleasent surprise and I highly recommend them.  However, I was disappointed in the carpaccio, of which normally I am a huge fan.  It just seemed bland to me, and it seemed the meat didn't have the quality I have come to appreciate in a dish of this style.  For entrees we had the Lamb and the chicken.  Both were decent, but seemed to lack punch, or uniqueness to make them stand out.  I found myself searching for something that seemed to never show up.  The food here by no means is bad, it just is your average fair that you expect from a little neighborhood joint.

Wine:  2.5 stars.  I brought in my own wine for the main course and we ordered by the glass both before and after.  The by the glass selection is poor, with not much exciting.  It is quaffable, but that is about it.  The wine list is definitely well thought out with most regions of popular Italy represented.  There are only a few good choices, hence the 2.5 rating here, but I can tell some effort went into building a small list of wines to try and match the style of food.  I would love to see them add some items on the list from some not so typical parts of Italy that have now emerged on the scence and are producing fabulous wines (and at better prices than the famous regions).  Prices on the wine list here are very fair.

Overall: I have to say I had my hopes up for Venticello and came away a little disappointed.  I was really looking for something a little more unique, but rather I felt the same as when I walk out of any regular Italian restaurant in North Beach.  If you live walking distance, I recommend trying Venticello, because it is a decent meal and a nice quiet place to talk and enjoy anothers company.  Would I travel across the city (or further) to come here, probably not.
author: Scott P.

description: Amazing. I'm not a big fan of Italian restaurants as someone from an Italian family, I'm not easily impressed. Everything we ordered can simply be described as amazing. Prawns appetizer is a blessing from baby Jesus himself. The gnocci equally amazing. Only knock would be our waiter, who seemed to think he was an Italian model too good to be working in a restaurant. We got the majority of our service from a young lady who wasn't even our server.
author: Chris J.

description: Good food, poor service.  Had to wait 1/2 hour past reservation time to be seated.  Waiter seemed disinterested.
author: Chris B.

description: Ate here with 2 other couples last evening.  It was the second time in a couple years and the food was excellent despite some spotty service issues.  Also they do NOT gouge you on the wine prices.  Highly recomended.
author: Milo D.

description: Another great neighborhood secret! Love the antipasto which consist of grilled endive, zucchini, and eggplant, and sometimes even ripe tomato, mozzarella, and marinated shrimp on radicchio. Their thin crust pizzas, house made ravioli are other things to try out.
author: Juliane N.

description: Besides the waiter who seemed to be a huge douche, this place had a lot of great things to offer. For starters the broiled garlic in olive oil dipping sauce was addicting. I can't even tell you how many cloves of garlic I must have eaten or how many times I must have thought about slipping out of the restaurant and buying a zip lock bag to steel the sauce out of there in. . . . Just talking about it right now makes me want to sprint over there  So I ordered the Venticello:  Baby Lettuce in a Honey Mustard Dressing with Toasted Walnuts and Gorgonzola Cheese and the Ravioli di Formaggio al Pomodoro:Herb & Goat Cheese Ravioli in a Roma Tomato, Basil and Garlic Sauce which ended up being  were delicious and  tasty. The flavors were all very rich and definitely did wonders for my pallet. Each bite made my mouth water more and more and crave for the next one to come.
author: stash e.

description: If you've got some extra coin in your pocket, looking to celebrate a special occasion or wanting to impress that special someone, you should make a point to reserve a table at Venticello.  Tucked away on Nob Hill along the Cable Car Line, this tiny Italian restaurant will leave you wanting more.  They rotate the menu with the seasons and ingredients available at the time.  The Venticello salad is a nice way to start your meal and their list of entrees offer something different for every palate.  Impressive and expansive wine list is also to be noted.  If you're in a rush, or looking for cliche Italian food, this is not the place for you.  Sit back, enjoy the fire, sip your wine and savor the food.
author: DamnGringo X.

description: I love this restaurant. Delicious pear and gorgonzola pizza, carbonara, sole, and ravioli. It is San Francisco at its most picturesque- cable car clattering by and a view of the Transamerica Pyramid and Bay Bridge. Service is usually attentive, but can be a little distant on busy nights. One of my favorite things is on warm nights (those few we have!) they open the huge picture windows in the front, and it feels like you're eating outside.
author: Noelle Q.

description: Super heavy sauce on the sole, prawns were amazing, good wine selection, amazing atmosphere with great views of the city from the streets, and a beautiful date, what more could i ask for? Next time maybe two bottles of wine and i will try the filet. Overall great experience away from the "scene", what California is all about to those who grew up here.
author: Bryan M.

description: Utterly delicious food, warm ambiance, reasonable prices--I loved this place. Started with grilled figs and pancetta-yum! The mushroom gnocci was surprizingly light, but the porcini flavor was wonderfully intense. Ditto the pork sausage with pasta. Beautiful fennel flavor hit just the right note. When I couldn't decide on the wine, our server let me try a taste. Best of all, the host was friendly, funny--and accommodating. Managed to find a table for us on a busy Saturday and made us feel SO welcome. The place was jammed solid, so there was really no reason he had to go all out for us, but he did. They don't take anything for granted here. Bravo.
author: jay s.

description:
3.5 stars

Great neighborhood restaurant. Always packed on the wkends. Love the rustic setting and high ceilings. 

The best best dish they have is the eggplant appetizer - fine for non-eggplant lovers as it is covered in hot bubbly cheese and tomato sauce. so delish!

They regularly have fresh fish specials - comes wrapped in parchment and is so juicy and flavorful, best entree. The mushroom gnocci is pretty good as well. Do NOT get the pizza app - i got the pear / gorgonzola one and it was so bad i couldn't eat it.

Romantic but also a good place to meet up w friends. Warm and loud, its a great chill italian place to go
author: Shirley A.

description: One of my favorite restaurants in the city! Best carbonara in town no question!
author: Torres F.

description: One of my favorite SF restaurants! It is completely hidden. (i.e. NO TOURISTS!) and the food and service is fabulous - I've never been disappointed. It's also in a remarkable area...watching the Cable Car zoom down the hill is actually quite special, vs. annoying. It's the kind of place to impress someone who doesn't know the city, in my opinion.
author: Gina G.

description: A great place to go for a date. Daniel the host squeezed us in with no reservations, & Tim the wine guy & our waiter, was excellent. It was a good atmosphere. And even tho crowded, we felt like we were the only two. Great recommendations on the wine, all around excellent, attentive customer service.
author: Dapper D.

description:
this would be a great place for a date! you could take the cable car up to the restaurant on a foggy SF night and settle in with the wood burning stove in the back and a nice glass of wine... 
well, it's been a while since my last date but i WAS invited here for a work dinner and had the best spaghetti carbonara of my life. the server was very attentive, and another person in my party decided their food was not quite what they wanted and sent it back. normally i cringe with embarrassment when people send things back because i've watched too much food network and hell's kitchen,  but the waiter just smiled and brought them a new tasty looking dish.
i would love to have tried the pear/mascarpone wrapped in prosciutto but that will have to wait until next time.
author: leezah f.

description: I enjoy the ambiance, the staff is friendly, The food is excellent. I just park somewhere else and take a cab. I wouldn't drive and try to park. A small friendly bar when you walk in. The restaurant is quaint, charming, and well appointed.  I have received very nice service at Venticello. I must go again soon. I always meet very nice people there and it is a very friendly atmosphere.  I must go back soon. {repeating myself}
author: Angelina M.

description: Funny thing about reservations - anyone can take the reservation...it's the holding that's the hard part apparently. So, we made reservations for 8pm and arrived  precisely at 8. An hour later we were seated. Not once did anyone look after us while we patiently waited by the bar. We ended up asking for a coupla glasses of Prosecco just to have something, but there was *zero* communication about our table. Finally we're asking and get a half-assed "yeah - there's like a convention in town. We're waiting for them to leave. Then your table will be available." Well, it took an hour and once we were finally seated the place was totally deserted. I think there were two other tables besides ours at that point. Not once did anyone apologize or anything. It was bizarre really. The food was average. A decent meal with a nice over-priced bottle of Chianti. Service was ok once we finally got it. We ended up being the last table there and you could see the wait staff were just waiting for us to leave so they could as well. Overall, a pathetic display of non-professionalism, IMO. We'll not ever return or recommend it. There's *loads* better places in the city for the money. Oh yeah, they left the Prosecco off the bill. Big deal. Whatever man.
author: Viola M.

description: Has a pretty intimate feel to it.  The food was tasty, but not overly exciting.  I had the gnocci and it was more than satisfactory.
author: Robert R.

description: Very nice dinner. Chicken marsala tender and delicious.
author: Steve S.

description:
veal scallopini straight out of the refrigerator into the microwave covered in a candy sweet marsala sauce, tough enough to require a requested sharper knife - all this for twenty something dollars! enough said - go ANYwhere else for "Italian" food;  probably the worst dining experience we've had in a while
the mashed potatoes with garlic were good
the view ho-hum
service just odd
you can do better in your own home with canned sauce and packaged noodles
author: g r.

description: Great food, service and atmosphere. Nice place for a date!
author: Stephanie I.

description: When eating Italian in SF, I don't want North Beach and I don't want to make a reservation three weeks in advance. That said, you'll find me eating gnocchi in this great Nob Hill spot.
author: Philip M.

description: Delightful Italian fare: traditional salads and pastas make up the bulk of the menu.  All delicious.  Very cozy atmosphere.  The service was a little slow, but we were all thoroughly enjoying ourselves.
author: Amme P.

description: Delicious Italian appetizers and entrees.  Cozy atmosphere, and gracious staff balance out the leisurely pace. A wonderful date locale!
author: Julia W.

description:
i was expecting a lot more out of venticello especially since it's held in such high regard.  we were underwhelmed by each dish and we don't see ourselves going back here in the near future.  

my wife started with some caprese that the kitchen was nice of enough to make even though it was not on the menu.  unfortunately it lacked seasoning and fell flat.  i got the carrot/ginger soup and i couldn't find any trace of ginger.  it tasted like muted carrot and needed salt and pepper to help me thru 50% of it.

for our mains, she got the herb goat cheese ravioli in a tomato, garlic basil sauce and i got the saffron risotto w/ "tiger" prawns.  the herb goat cheese filling for the ravioli was overly salty and tangy and i had a hard time getting thru the one piece that she had me try out.  my risotto looked and tasted like soupy over-cooked rice.  the flavors of the saffron were nice but the texture was bad for a risotto.  and the prawns were NOT tiger prawns.  tasted alright but i was expecting a real tiger prawn!

we ended the meal w/ a flourless chocolate torte and panna cotta.  both were good but the torte was a bit to rich with not enough strawberry puree and the panna cotta wasn't custardy enough for me.

it sucks that we didn't enjoy the meal more because it's truly a cute lil place.  parking here sucks for sure and you may end up scaling or stumbling thru the beautiful hills of this city.
author: Swarup B.

description: Love this place, one of my fav spots.  Service, food and atmosphere is hard to beat.  All home made pastas, and great apps.  Fun to eat at the bar as well.
author: Jennifer N.

description: It's cozy but you don't feel crowded.  The fireplace is great and the wait staff is very nice.  The food is always good. The pasta is perfect.  You can sit at the bar while you wait for a table.  The views from the windows are really neat.  There is valet parking since parking is challenging.
author: Julia H.

description: My husband and I came here to celebrate my birthday and it was a good experience (not great and minus two stars because our waiter was less than enthusiastic, my soup was bland, and we were sitting on top of our neighbors).  The food was good and the setting excellent.  I love that roasted garlic and olive oil dipping sauce they served with the warm foccacia bread.  Ask for a table at the window if you can and you'll get a fantastic view of the bay bridge.
author: Jen T.

description: We were lucky enough to grab a couple seats by the bar on a busy Saturday evening just before the Margaret Cho show at the Masonic.  We weren't so lucky trying to get into Nob Hill Cafe.  This place is lovely and cozy.  The bar sits upstairs overlooking the main dining room and has a warm and intimate feeling throughout the restaurant.  What a great view, too.  While obviously frazzled, the maitre d' was accommodating and polite, and quickly apologized for being "short" with us as soon as he got the chance.  We ordered a few small plates and a glass of wine each.  We got the carpaccio, the goat cheese ravioli, and the minestrone soup--all wonderful especially the ravioli.  Well, the server said he would put our orders in right away since we had a show to get to, but I didn't expect the food to come out so quick.  It was seriously like 10 minutes, but we weren't rushed at all.  We still ate at a leisurely pace and were out of there in time to catch Margaret's intro.  The bill for both of us came to about $80--very reasonable for SF and the quality of food we got.
author: Nisa N.

description: Wonderful neighborhood spot that usually offers a medium-high end dining experience for a reasonable price. Food quality is reliable and the ambiance makes it great for a date or just a nice weekday escape. I recommend the fire-grilled prawns wrapped in pancetta with a spicy chili sauce (note: they're not kidding about the spicy part), the Caesar salad, the homemade arugula and ricotta ravioli in fresh herb and butter cream sauce and the grilled lamb tenderloin.
author: Jason B.

description: Quite possibly the best restaurant in SF, as far as I'm concerned.  Everything I've ever had here is amazing.  Salad, gnocchi, pork loin, tuna, sea bass...  It feels like they perfected every dish and the service is always great.  I can't wait to go back and keep trying different dishes.
author: Jason D.

description: A Nob Hill treat.  Food and wine list is good.  Can be noisy and crowded.  I recommend taking a later reservation around 8:30-9:00 and enjoying yourself until they close up.  I've been there 5 times and have not been disappointed.
author: Keith S.

description: Got a reservation for 8 on really short notice, Had a fantastic dinner and great wine all in all reasonably priced.
author: Eric H.

description: Major disappointment. I heard great things about this spot and ended up with the worst service possible.The food was delicious and well done but I would never go back.
author: A D.

description: The food was amazing. Pork tenderloin perfectly cooked and the sauce, oh the sauce.  I was not blown away by the dessert, chocolate torte. I would reccommend going elsewhere.  The only disappointment was the proximity of the tables.  The place is so small, you are wedged into these tables and I felt like I was intruding on other people's conversations and vice versa. Not as "romantic" as they claim to be due to the lack of privacy.
author: Ruby S.

description: The perfect place if you are seeking a picture perfect San Francisco dining experience. Located in Nob Hill, Venticello takes fancy Italian dining to a new level.
author: Sue L.

description: We recently had our company holiday party here and it was great!  The staff was friendly, the food and drinks were excellent, and the ambience warm and festive. I would highly recommend it to anyone.
author: Rikki D.

description: This is a good place to give out of town guests a feel for a SF neighborhood restaurant. They have good lemoncello at Venticello.
author: Carson H.

description: Quaint.  Rustic.  Romantic.  This is fabulous cozy little restaurant.  As you walk in there is a very warm and inviting feeling about it.  The wine list is extensive and food is just great.  While I do enjoy Italian food it's not often the cuisine that jumps to mind when thinking about going out for dinner....but I love this place.
author: Rafael s.

description: A perfect solution for a pre-show dinner before heading to the Masonic Temple Auditorium performance. We were seated without reservations as long as we finished our dinner by 7:45 pm. Perfect. Its sister restaurant Nob Hill Restaurant was too small and crowded to accommodate us on a Sunday at 5:45 pm. The food is competent. The wine selection the same. This neighborhood restaurant was very warm, nice, and inviting. The overall experience was enjoyable. Tables are cozy enough to strike up a conversation with a neighboring table if you so choose.
author: Mike F.

description:
After reading some of the reviews, it looked like maybe Venticello hit a bad beginning of the year.  I usually come into restaurants having very low expectations, especially those that have a valet.  Sometimes the portions are too small, sometimes the food isn't for my palate and sometimes, I just don't like it.  But this time I was presently surprised when I arrive with my date at 9pm on a Saturday night without a reservation and they were able to seat us immediately with a choice of where we wanted to sit.  We chose to not go downstairs and stay upstairs in the bar area where we began our meal with pancetta wrapped shrimp which my date said was good, and I said was a little too burned.  Then I had gnocchi which had great consistancy but the mushroom sauce was a little too overseasoned (which to me is always better than underseasoned) and my date had the fettucine with a ground pork tomato sauce (superb!) and then for dessert we had a shot of fernet-branca each.  

Over all - the service was OK, but the fresh pasta and great sauces made up for it.  The place is beautiful and set in a cute neighborhood.  Its an upscale version of what I would imagine to be an elegant traditional italian experience.
author: Thanh C.

description: Absolutely fantastic!  This was the first time I went here, and everything was fantastic.  The close quarters were kind of nice-- like old italy in a very expensive area of town.  The food was outstanding.  Everything melted in our mouths.  Furthermore, the waiters were speaking Italian to some of the guests (It just must've been that good).
author: Avinash R.

description: Very nice place.  I made a huge mistake of not checking before I went there with my date and was seriously underdressed.  Next time I think when I see "Nob Hill" I best pay attention.  Other than that snafu, the dinner was superb.  I had the pasta special while my date had a tasty fish plate.  Overall very nice impression and ambiance.  Only reason for only four stars was that the waiter was a bit pushy, and the table we were seated is was sort of in the way of a corner table.  So much so, I ended up with a man's ass in my face.  Not cool.
author: Kayne Y.

description:
great location...my family had a corner table to celebrate a special occasion.  wonderful ambiance as well.  

the food was good, but for the price?  no way.  wayy to expensive for what you get, ive had far better italian food in the city.  you are paying for the nob hill location.  

we did have a very enjoyable evening, full of delicious pastas, decent service and  lovely wine.  however if what you are after is exceptional italian food, not exceptional italian food prices, go elsewhere.
author: Kristin K.

description:
My recent visit to Venticello was a bit of a disappointment.  I've always liked that site, even back when it was Yerba Buena Village (if anyone remembers back that far.)
This time, the food was good, as always--good, basic, hearty Italian food well prepared and presented--and the service was pleasant.  However, the restaurant itself is showing a bit of wear.  The chairs are a bit wobbly, the walls could use some repainting and refreshing (the look is becoming very dated), and the lighting could be tweaked a bit.  It wouldn't take much to bring Venticello back to the elegant little neighbourhood boite I so fondly remember.
author: Tom R.

description: I really like this place especially for showing off the city to out of town guests. Its in a picturesque neighborhood and the food is really really good. Friendly staff and fantastic ambiance!
author: All About Town ..

description: Great out-of-the-way restaurant perched on the Washington Street hill just above Taylor. Small, rustic, warm and welcoming. Not loud. So nice to be able to carry on a conversation without having to raise your voice. The staff was friendly and attentive. The waiter recommended a bottle of 2004 Rosso di Montalcino (Sangiovese) to go with our lamb and filot mignon, and it was a good choice. The food was very good. A good date place. Pretty intimate and unhurried. I'd go again. :-)
author: Steve R.

description: Excellent service.  Went there for a birthday dinner with five other girls, three of us shared a salad, pasta course, and entree and the chef split each item three ways for us.  Not only was that part cool, but the food and wine were excellent as well.  Good ambiance and not noisy too, would probably be great for a date night.
author: Lauren R.

description:
Oh my yum! My boyfriend and I stumbled upon Venticello last night. It was on my radar as a restaurant to dine at, but I had no clue where it was. We were walking around the neighborhood looking for a place to eat and found it! I was so excited. We walked in and they were able to take us right away. The restaurant was so cute and rustic. Our server was very nice and answered all my questions about the pasta and sauces and what was good on the menu. 

For our meal, we shared the Heirloom Tomato on Arugula, topped with a sun dried tomato balsamic vinaigrette. It was divine. For my main course I had the Fettuccine Con Salsiccia. Oh my, it was hands down the best Pasta Dish I've ever had, better than any pasta I had while in Italy. Jon had the Gnocchi Al Funghi. Yum. It was so tender and delicious. I think when we go back I will have the Gnocchi with the Salsiccia sauce.

I will definitely being going back to Venticello, and will be encouraging everyone I know to go as well.
author: Courtney M.

description: AMAZING!!! Such good food and ambiance. I was worried because I'm not a huge fan of dinners at Nob Hill Cafe and I heard they were connected, but this place is worlds above Nob Hill Cafe. The best date place and great service. The food prices aren't even THAT pricey, it's the wine that gets you...
author: Jessica H.

description: Simply Amazing! I have been here a few times and ordered family style with friends and nothing we have tried has fallen short of incredible. From the appetizers to the desserts, this ristorante will exceed all of your expectations. The wine list is also wonderful with a wide array of choices from local to lovely Italian options with something appropriate for any price range. I would also say that this is an incredibly romantic restaurant as it is very intimate and the staff are attentive but not overly involved in your experience. I am almost hesitant to leave a review rather than keeping it a small secret nob hill gem!
author: Jessi B.

description:
Before you walk in, take a look around and if you don't say to yourself, 'Damn that's a great view' there might be something wrong with you.  Now combine that with some great food and wine and it would be hard not to create a very romantic environment for anyone.
My girlfriend and I finally made it here after many friends kept telling her about it.  I loved my chicken dish with mushrooms.  It had a lot of flavors, but none too overpowering and it was also very moist and juicy.  Our service was great, as Mario recommended some good wines to go with our meals.
The inside is like a classy, rustic European restaurant.  Even though there were some people in suits, others like myself were in casual wear and I still felt 100% comfortable there.
Definitely an ideal neighborhood restaurant that is worth going to for delicious food in a cozy atmosphere with great service.
author: Derek H.

description:
I've only been here twice but it is awesome.  The food, service and ambiance are all excellent.

My favorite dish is the mushroom gorgonzola gnocchi, but you can forget about doing anything else after you eat this....it is like a dessert it's so rich.

The filet mignon was also very good.

I've never seen it not empty during peak hours so I guess you would be silly to try and squeeze in during primetime without a reservation.
author: Brian W.

description: My husband and I wanted Italian dinner that was walking distance from our hotel on Nob Hill. After reading reviews on yelp, I called for a Friday night reservation on Friday afternoon. We couldn't get in until 8:30, but it was worth it. The atmosphere was very cozy, the waiter was very helpful and helped us when we couldn't decide. We ended up splitting the first course and the desert. The food was very good. We enjoyed our experience and would highly recommend this restaurant. It is a bit expensive, but oh well that's life in the city.
author: Pat H.

description: After years of wanting to come to this restaurant, I finally came to Venticello Ristorante for my birthday dinner and was thoroughly impressed.  I was in a really pissy mood when I got there (please see The Ambassador review), but Venticello made my bad mood go away.  It is a beautiful restaurant with high ceilings and a romantic, villa feel.  And the valet parking makes this an easy restaurant to visit in the city.  No valet, no visit.  We started with champagne and wine--only the best of course--as they have an extensive wine list.  I ordered the prawns with spicy chile sauce and the sole which came with veggies and mashed potatoes.  All of it was very good.  The portions were actually large for this type of restaurant and I could only eat about half of my entree.  I also got a birthday tiramisu which Iis probably one of the better ones I've tasted.  Excellent service.  They asked to take my coat when I got there and to me that is very classy and polite.  I have a very fond memory of Venticello and would love to come back to try more.  Minus one star because I expected better views.  I was told by many that they had amazing views, but to me it was just like looking out the window down the street.  Perhaps my standards are high because I have a view of the Golden Gate Bridge from my room.
author: Vanessa Z.

description: Cute little nook of a restaurant in rich hill. The menu is concise and everything sounds tempting. All the pasta dishes are made with homemade pasta. The wait staff is experienced and very fast. They had no problems splitting plates for us and being very respectful about our unsureness about exactly what we wanted to eat and all of the different personalities at the table. The food was good, not orgasmic or an explosive experience by any means, but good, the portions were just right-no crazy servings just because it's italian food but just enough so you don't have to take home leftovers or feel yucky afterwards. Atmosphere is ok, a bit loud for being so small and romantic feeling, and the new age Kenni G stuff they had on the speakers at a loud level was annoying and left many of us at table out of the conversation. Overall, a good spot when you don't want to venture out onto the creative food landscape-safe place to eat.
author: Samantha J.

description: I was attracted to the lovely small space, but was forwarned of the quality by my first bite - of mediocre bread served with a dish of olive oil mixed with STALE chopped garlic.  A very bland "Cesar" salad with one sad  little pale anchovy followed.  Mediocre describes the rest of the meal.  My gnocchi were tender but the sauce had no distinguishing taste other than salt, which became saltier the more I ate - and Im not one to avoid salt.  My guest's risotto, with little flavor or creaminess, was even less appetizing. Not a place to revisit.
author: martha B.

description: Venticello - the name certainly conjures up warm images of Italy and the appeal of a fine italian dining experience. It's also in a pleasant neighborhood location in Nob Hill. Unfortunately, the experience, while not bad in any respect, did not meet expectations. I had the prawns with some kind of hot sauce (not authentic Italian style methinks). We also had a pasta and pork dish. Both were pleasant enough but unexceptional. The desert menu was the usual limited stereotypical Italian Tiramasu, Panna cotta etc, with the Tiramasu being far from the best I've tasted. Come on folks - get creative. Italy has more to offer than this tired overused list. The service was formally polite but had little authentic, patron inspired distinction to it. The decor was also your typical washed wall fresco look. In the end, not much to write home about and I don't intend to return.
author: AntonEgo C.

description: Came for dinner.  Ordered a glass of proseco.   Flat.  Then I ordered the pizza with arugula and mushrooms.  Bad.  It was a tough piece of cardboard that was as difficult to cut, as it was to chew.  But what really irritated me was that it seemed the bread component was an old, cold Boboli (remember that stuff?) with raw arugula and mushrooms tossed on top and then covered with a bit of Parmesan from a vegetable peeler.  The risotto with shrimp and scallop was dry.  Think Rice-a-Roni, but this was no San Francisco treat, especially at $19.  The zabaione was a tablespoon of flat custard plopped on unripe, hard, green strawberries.  While the service wasn't bad--at least not as bad as other reviews have suffered, the food made the experience unrecoverable.  Perhaps an off night, but I really wouldn't recommend this local restaurant.  There are other, better places to go in the neighborhood.
author: QuodE D.

description:
my favorite italian restaurant in san francisco. serves amazing food, and is always consistent. the wait staff is nice enough, though the hostess seems to be imbued with an unhealthy amount of self-importance, considering it's a neighborhood place and she's not all that much to look at -- usually stuffed into a pair of leggings 3 sizes too small. 

our waiter always remembers us, and the bottle of wine we like to order. the ambiance is wonderful, this is a perfect place for a date, or a dinner with a group of friends. the lighting is low, so everyone looks good. 

this place is also good for the single diner, who can chose to sit at the bar. you don't need a reservation, we never make them unless its at 7 on a friday or saturday. then i would recommend it.
author: cassandra v.

description: I live just up the street from Venticello and have eaten there twice. Food is good, not outstanding, with very small portions, and the prices very high.  As far as the atmosphere goes.....if you like sitting literally so close to the people next to you that you can smell their food, in the basement of an apartment building, I suppose you'll like this. No view, no parking, dark....yet, I laugh everytime time  I see people waiting outside at night , telling their friends that "this is their hidden treasure" of San Francisco neighborhood restaurants!  I guess they don't around much as this just doesn't fil the bill.
author: Paul M.

description: Yum-O! Bring a big appetite becasue you are going to want everything. I'd share to taste more, but for me the gnocchi and the veal are a must. I could eat here every night.
author: Cbr A.

description: Daniel is just spectactular!Every time I come to town I eat here .More for the service than anything else.
author: Jack M.

description: overall , pretty swanky place.  we mosied in (is that a word?) after a taxing day at the Nob Hill Spa (yawn).... no reservations on a sunday night.  no problem.  place was busy but only about half full.  no one on the upstairs area.  i was going to raise an objection to the host seating us upstairs - alone - but then i thought that the upstairs was nicely designed and pretty and solitary so it was just as fine as being seated with the masses down below.  so i can't say that i'd prefer upstairs to down.  they both seem cool, but , of course, next time, i'd go downstairs since i was up this first time.  any case, the pizzetta wasn't the accomplishment of the ages.  it was a bit too big for an appetizer and wasn't terribly inventive.  some veggies on baked bread was about it, but the salad and the ravioli and the well done tiramisu saved the day.  i really liked the most important dish, the ravioli the most.  the wine list was good.  i had a glass of red while the girl had a glass of prosecco.  ambiance and decor ... wine list and service .... entrees and dessert... all very nice.  the lack of a truly great dessert wine and the pizzetta's plainness were the only thing i can hold against it.  next time you're in the neighborhood, give it a try.  not the ridiculous wait of some of the spots in the hood but very nice addition.
author: dan h.

description: Perfect restuarant for a special occasion. Good food, varied wine list and an "authentic" feel to it. Plus you can add to the experience by taking a cable car to/from it and enjoying the eastward views over the Financial District with the Bay Bridge behind. There are a lot of excellent choices for Italian food in this area, but Venticello is high on my list.
author: Colin M.

description:
one of my absolute favorites! the service is almost always warm and lovely, the wines fabulous, and the food is super delicious.

the pear and marscapone appetizer, radicchio salad, fettucine with sausage and filet mignon are ALL stellar.

plus, they have a very good vin santo and biscotti dessert.

GO GO GO! So incredibly delicious every time i've been. i dream about it now.
author: Lady L.

description:
I am very sad as I write this review.  My wonderful memories of this restaurant are now just that - memories.  I planned a very special evening for my husband and I to celebrate his birthday.  I chose Venticello as the restaurant because I remember it being super romantic with delicious food... my favorite thing about the whole experience was the bottle of Ridge Zinfandel we drank... which unfortunately Venticello had nothing to do with the production of my favorite part of the evening.  
I made the reservation at least a month in advance.  I told them it was a very special night (hubby's bday) and that we definitely wanted to sit downstairs and could we possibly have a table by the window.  We arrived right on time for our 8pm dinner reservation and had to wait for over 1/2 hour to be seated.  Not only did they originally try to seat us upstairs, but the table we eventually got was butted up against a wall with no real charm.
